Évaluation publiée le 7 décembre 2019
Здравствуйте.
Эту игру приобрёл по скидке и даже этих денег она не стоит. Вообще не могу понять самого себя, зачем её купил, ну да ладно.
Действие происходит в космосе, на станции, сюжет спойлерить не буду, хотя по сути мне было всё понятно уже всё в самом начале. Глубокий сюжет? Да ладно вам, ходишь по станции и перематываешь время, чтобы услышать тупые разговоры членов экипажа или залезть в их переписку. Ощущение было, что детей послали работать на станцию, судя по их манере речи и поведению, Вот и вся игра. А, ну да, можно предметы двигать руками, обалдеть правда. Приятная графика, больше ничего положительного не нашёл.
Покупать её не стоит, хотя это конечно вам решать.
Особо укажу, что здесь присутствуют однополые отношения, в игре прямо какой-то акцент делается на этом, Мне честно говоря всё равно, но есть люди, которым это не нравится.

9.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 janvier 2018
Contexte géopolitique et SF très bien travaillés. J'ai beaucoup aimé le thème de l'IA tel qu'abordé ici.

Le suspense est bien construit et la fin fonctionne. Les vies et personnalités des personnages sont assez intéressantes et développées, même si on va pas se mentir, le jeu reste assez court.

Le gameplay des scènes enregistrées qu'on peut rembobinner est simple mais très efficace. Toutes les scènes enregistrées contiennent plusieurs discussions simultanées et les personnages se déplacent, ça casse la linéarité, c'est bien utilisé.

Le level design est plutôt bon, les visuels superbes.

Recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 janvier 2021
A stirring, one-sitting, time-rewinding detective game in the vein of Event 0, Obra Dinn, or The Under Presents with a higher emphasis on narrative and emotional interest than quantifying observations through gameplay. Tacoma is set in a relatively probable sci-fi future that applies advanced AR to interplanetary stations. The technology is a suitably diegetic way of navigating recordings or UI that also works well with the station’s art direction. Using silhouetted models for each crew member is a clever way of circumventing the potential hazard of uncanny facial animations. Assigning each person a unique color, symbol, voice, and nationality make them easy to quickly learn. Communicating through body language, vague text, and a handful of photos invites the player to further participate in the story by contributing their own inferences. As with Gone Home, what you take away from Tacoma will reflect your personal exploration of the game’s plot and environmental subtleties.
 
CasualCheetah

1,262 produits enregistrés

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Non recommandé
4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 octobre 2018
Interaktivní filmek jménem Tacoma zabere dvě hodiny, obsahuje zajímavou myšlenku, ale téměř vše ostatní je ve hře špatně.
Hlavní hrdinka, najatá společností Venturis se má porozhlédnout po opuštěné vesmírné stanici TACOMA, kterou postihla nevysvětlitelná katastrofa. Má zjistit, co se přihodilo, nahrát záznamy (na palubě Tacomy se vše zaznamenávalo v podobě humpolácké virtuální reality) a přinést desku s umělou inteligencí lodi jménem ODIN zpět do sídla korporace.
Hlavní hrdinka nejprve zjišťuje, že vlivem nehody došlo ke katastrofálnímu úniku kyslíku a poškození komunikačních kanálů. Posádka tedy spěje k neodvratné smrti, později se však ukáže, že šlo o intriky společnosti Venturis, která obětuje posádku jedné ze svých orbitálních stanic, aby prosadila zákon o možnosti provozování autonomních vesmírných zařízení a tím mnohonásobně zvýšila svůj profit. Nebojte se ale milé děti, posádka se nakonec zachrání, a umělá inteligence ODIN nebude v sídle společnosti smazána, ale bude osvobozena aktivisty, protože každá inteligence by měla být svobodná, byť je umělá. Společnosti Venturis se nakonec podaří prolobovat výše zmíněný zákon, takže to vlastně skončilo happyendem - všichni jsou spokojeni a jestli neumřeli, tak tam žijí dodnes.

KLADY:
+ Bezproblémový chod v Linuxu
+ Zajímavá myšlenka

ZÁPORY:
- Hrozná grafika, kvůli které jsem se nedokázal identifikovat s postavami
- linearita
- simulátor chůze
- krátký herní čas - 2 hodiny
- nezáživná hratelnost
- absence češtiny
- velikost 10 GB neodpovídá ani délce hry ani její prezentaci
HODNOCENÍ:
Prvotina studia Fullbright (Gone Home) mě nadchla. Jejich druhý počin (Tacoma) mě naopak znechutila. Vývojáři nejprve okopírovali koncept své první hry a umístili ji do prostředí vesmírné stanice, poté přidali zajímavou zápletku a následně přidali "COOL grafiku vidlácké virtuální reality". Když si pak po dvou hodinách říkáte, že by to už konečně mohlo začít, začnou se pouze odvíjet závěrečné titulky. Alespoň, že technická stránky hry v Linuxu je bezproblémová.
Hodnotím 40%.
 
majakmp3

Recommandé
4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 avril 2018
I never liked Gone Home. Was expecting this game to be more of the same. Happy to be wrong. All the details tucked away inside plentiful nooks and crannies really make Tacoma worth celebrating.

Gone Home was a little too arranged for my liking. I saw where the story was going. The linearity was right in front of me and I hated the game for it. In contrast, Tacoma’s crew quarters feel thoroughly lived in – a welcome contrast to the stark corridors and functional work spaces you’ll visit in between – and getting to watch these characters’ personal lives slowly bleed into their public working personas is absolutely fascinating. To give an early example, you might discover that one of the missing crew mates has been reading (rather endearingly) a book on ‘banter for the inspired social climber’ in his personal AR desktop to help him settle in with this new group of strangers, and you can see the results of this play out in the reconstructed conversations you’ll discover throughout the rest of the game. It’s a brilliant meshing of the game’s various exploration objectives, and it wasn’t long before I found each crew member’s individual story to be just as compelling as the central mystery. And that ending. Oh, that ending! Absolutely superb.

Thank you developers. On a side note I played with my wife. We really enjoyed playing your game together. 10/10
 
Eliian

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
6.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 février 2018
Amitjyoti (Amy) Ferrier, deve recuperare dalla stazione spaziale Tacoma (parte di una mega corporazione chiamata Venturis Corporation) Odin, un intelligenza artificiale. Oltre a raccogliere i dati sullo staff umano presente sulla stazione, registrati attraverso un sistema di realtà aumentata.

Tacoma è una storia interattiva in cui l'elemento ludico è totalmente inesistente, l'unica cosa da fare è seguire il percorso stabilito da coloro che l'hanno creato. Nessuna deviazione. Nessuna scelta.

Le storie, anche quelle più lineari, possono ancorarsi a personaggi interessanti per risultare meno noiose. L'equipaggio della stazione spaziale Tacoma è costituito da persone diverse, che si tratti del colore della pelle o l'orientamento sessuale. Sono persone diverse l'una dall'altra ma ♥♥♥ problemi che possono risultare famigliari.
Ma questi personaggi non si raccontano. Non si capisce il lutto di EV, l'insicurezza di Bert, il senso di colpa di Serah. Grande sbaglio da parte degli scrittori.

Non mi sento di consigliare questo "gioco", il costo è eccessivo per ciò che può offrire.
 
Nightingale

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 mars 2018
Avis assez mitigé sur ce jeu que je viens de terminer.

Le level design est vraiment agréable, c'est beau et immersif. On se croirait vraiment dans une petite station spatiale avec tout le nécessaire pour y bosser et y vivre. Quelques interactions par ci par là avec le materiel, les objets divers etc.

Les doublages sont de qualité. Et l'ambiance sonore dans la station est vraiment parfaite.

L'histoire semble interessante et dévoile quelques secrets au fil du jeu

Mais !

La fin est déçevante, pas de grosse surprise.
Les personnages ne sont pas plus attachants que ça et on ne prends pas plus plaisir à lire les informations les concernant
Ca reste assez mou dans l'ensemble.
20€ pour 2h de jeu en prenant bien son temps, c'est vraiment court ...

Je laisse tout de même un avis plutôt positif en espérant un jeu du même acabit mais plus complet
 
Amla
1,562 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 novembre 2017
É difícil dar 'recomendado' pra esse jogo. Não por ele ser ruim - ele é ótimo no que se apresenta: um walking sim imersivo e focado em contar uma história -, só que os elementos que ele te coloca e, principalmente, na forma que ele te apresenta, são tão bons, mas tão bons, que eu fico decepcionado por quão pouco aproveitado foi todo potencial que ele poderia ter.

Você é Amy, uma terceirizada contratada para recolher os dados de uma estação chamada Tacoma, na qual 6 tripulantes estão desaparecidos. Sua missão é bem simples: pegar seu pad, espetar nas paredes de cada repartição da estação, fazer o download dos dados e ir embora. Mas enquanto você espera pelos looongos downloads, você pode ir explorando e descobrindo o que aconteceu ali. Uma tecnologia especial permitia a gravação em realidade aumentada (RA) de tudo que acontecia por lá, e você pode recuperar essas gravações pra saber como os tripulantes viviam, o que conversavam, suas vontades, as intrigas, os namoros, e conforme ir encaixando as pistas, desvendar enfim os acontecimentos dali.

O jogo te apresenta muito bem esse conceito, e (pelo menos comigo) fiquei fascinado pela forma que você interage com a gravação. Você pode retroceder e adiantar as gravações como quiser, e o mais interessante é que as 'cenas' são gravadas do espaço inteiro em um take só, então cada uma das pessoas tem suas próprias 'mini-cenas'. Por exemplo, você está assistindo a gravação e duas pessoas estão conversando, quando uma delas é interrompida por duas mulheres, perguntando se eles pode ir até o depósito onde as duas estão. Então eles vão até lá e os quatro tem outra conversa. Só que se você retroceder a gravação, vai descobrir que toda uma outra mini-cena aconteceu com as duas no depósito, ao mesmo tempo que aquela que você estava assistindo antes. Isso cria toda uma imersão na qual eu achei fantástica. O problema é que isso acontece no máximo umas 4-5 vezes no jogo inteiro. É muito pouco.

O jogo tem uma duração de 2 a 4 horas, isso se você gostar de explorar. Se você rushar, não dura nem 1,5 hora. Além disso, a história é um pouco mal executada. No inicio você descobre detalhes sobre as vidas de cada tripulante, começa a entender seus medos, suas vontades, os porques de cada um, e tudo parece muito interessante. Só que logo cai por terra depois de um 'acontecimento' que faz com que todos eles se tornem vazios e sem emoção. Todo ânimo que você cria em começar a entender cada tripulante se torna segundo plano após isso. Uma das cenas finais, por exemplo, é uma gravação de 22 minutos. Quando eu vi aquilo eu me animei demais, achando que a gravação ia fazer altas revelações, só que na verdade 90% da gravação está 'corrompida' e você só consegue ver dois trechos, que somados dá pouco mais que 3 minutos. Fora que todo mistério é contado em 4 aúdios finais de 1 minuto cada, o que foi bem broxante pelo menos pra mim..

Tacoma é excelente na proposta, mas poderia ser mais. Num escopo maior, com uma história mais rica, mais imensiva, teria tudo para ser um clássico moderno. Pra mim vai ser um jogo no qual eu tive prazer em jogar, mas infelizmente não vai ser um que conseguiu me marcar.

Recomendo pra quem gosta de walking simulators, mas pegue em promoção.
 
raphadura
1,344 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 aout 2017
This is a game entirely focused on exploration and narrative. You explore an abandoned space station to retrieve the AI hardware that is left on the station.

While doing so you get to know the crew that lived there and what happened to them. This is done by examining notes/letters/computers and other objects.

Also you get recorded "memories" in which you can observe the crew (which are represented by holograms). You can rewind/fast-foward these recordings to repeat a certain scene or follow different crew members and see what their were up to.

While it is nice to observe the body language of the different characters, what I found really enjoyable was that it enabled simultaneous story telling. For example: After you listened to a father speaking to his son another crew member walks in. The father asked her something regarding his health and she seems distracted and a bit annoyed when answering. Now you can rewind the memory and follow her and find out that the father interrupted her in a important conversation with the ship AI, explaning her annoyance. To be able to see the mindset of the different crewmember before/after conversations or their private thoughts when they split from the group is a lot more engaging than mere audiologs and a great addition to games with enviromental story telling.

The plot featured some sci-fi elements and touches upon AI and the corporate world in regards to automation.

It is however a niche game and definitely not for everyone. If you want heavy gameplay and get bored with reading through logs or hearing conversations, then I would not recommend it. Also, while there is a good overall plot which is a bit more adventurous, a lot of the fun for me comes from the fact that the station and the characters feel very real and have "mundane" lives. So if you care more about people who save the world or superheroes etc. and find relatable and "normal" characters not interesting this game may not be for you.

Also the game will not hold your hand in regard to the story. It is very nice paced and the different plot elements are discussed/mentioned often. However you need to put some effort into the game and be more thorough in exploring than your average first-person-shooter game. If you do not listen to the memory recordings or read through notes/computers etc. and like to just rush through the game, the ending will feel abrupt and not satisfying.

It is also relatively short ( I needed 7 hours to complete it, but I am a very thorough player, I would guess the average would be around 3-4 hours. Quality wise these 3-4 hours are among the best you can find, but I am a very big fan of walking sims and I know many people would object to my evaluation.

The voice acting is really good on all characters and graphically it is just great. The space station feels realistic and actually lived in and the attention to detail is insane. You can read detailed cautions and warning on the back of medicine bottles, observe the rotating rings of the space stations through the windows or just enjoy the view of the universe as the sunlight slowly moves across the room over a cup-ring stained table on which a guitar with one string snapped is leaned against.

This game greatest strengths are a relatable and fleshed out cast of characters and a very detailed space station to explore. If you have played and enjoyed games like Firewatch, Gone Home or What Remains of Edith Finch, or loved finding out about the people in Bioshock through audiologs and exploration and would not see the gunplay as a requirement for your enjoyment of the latter, I would highly recommend it.

If you are a fan of the genre I would say the full price is worth it, if you are not or if the shortness is a dealbreaker for you I would suggest to simply wishlist it and buy it on sale.
 
Planet Rin
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Évaluation publiée le 16 septembre 2017
It's a lovely game. I'm glad it exists, and it was a great deal of fun. If you don't like walking simulators, nothing here will change your mind.

I did like it a deal less than Gone Home, though. With six crewmembers there just isn't the time that Gone Home had to tell the little sister's story inside and out with all six of them. They all get equal weight, and so all their stories are doomed to be slightly shallow and unsatisfying. The end-of-game reveal seems far too rushed and hasty. I hope they can find a way of doing better next time.
 
makersley
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 février 2020
Начну издалека. В своё время разработчики из "Fullbright" выпустили игру "Gone Home", у которой на момент моего прохождения было много положительных отзывов в Steam и которая понравилась многим... но не мне из-за простоватого сюжета, который не удивлял и не компенсировал отсутствие геймплея (вы даже можете ознакомиться с моим обзором почти 6-летней давности, просто нажав сюда). Но вот от тех же разработчиков выходит некая "Tacoma", собравшая хорошие оценки (на данный момент 87% положительных отзывов) и заинтересовавшая меня своим сеттингом: пустой космический корабль, исчезнувший экипаж, атмосфера одиночества, царящая на корабле… В общем, игра обещала приятное прохождение, ведь даже без геймплея (напомню, «Tacoma» - это бродилка, «симулятор ходьбы») можно было бы создать хороший сюжет и атмосферу. Но по сослагательному наклонению вы, наверняка, поняли, что у разработчиков те 2 пункта не получились.

Из плюсов – приятная графика и исследование локаций и самих персонажей. Вы «взламываете» (в действительности, вместо просто открытия файла вы нажимаете и просто наблюдаете 1-2 секунды «взлома») файлы членов экипажа, читаете их сообщения, из которых вы можете узнать их мотивацию работы на корабле «Tacoma», также можете ходить в их каюты и наблюдать, что же они делали в свободное время. Вдобавок, они любят разделяться компаниями, уходить куда-то и шептаться, причём всё это происходит параллельно, и приходиться перематывать записи, чтоб послушать всех. И вроде бы на словах это интересно, а на первой локации уж тем более… Вот только вы будете это делать на протяжении всей игры! И это невероятно скучно!!

И вот, нас нагружают всей этой информацией, чтоб мы прониклись персонажами, поняли всю тяжесть их жизни… Вот только этого не происходит из-за того, что за то небольшое время (примерно 3 часа) нам не раскрывают в полной мере персонажей, их ощущаешь как набор штрихов, черт характеров, но не как полноценных личностей. Единственные персонажи, за которых можно хоть как-то переживать на фоне остальных, - так это врач и биолог, т.к. ты действительно видишь их сомнения, колебания, и ко всему прочему усиливает те чувства то, что они обращаются к ИИ, видя в нём последнюю надежду.

Ладно, с персонажами получилось не совсем гладко, а что с сюжетом?.. Ну, тут разработчики решили повторить свою простую формулу: история тут простейшая, неглубокая и впоследствии неинтересная. Если в начале хот какая-то интрига есть, то в конце вместо какого-то умного заключения или концовки, которая оставит впечатление и заставит задуматься, перед вами просто ставят факт: компании могут ради достижения своей цели могут пожертвовать жизнями невинных людей… Вау, такого, конечно, никто нигде не видел.

С атмосферой ещё хуже – её нет: всё подсвечено, из-за чего чувство одиночества и в какой-то мере загадочности пропадает.

Что же в итоге? «Tacoma» оказалась чистым проходняком, хотя потенциал был. Лично я не рекомендую к прохождению.
 
daniel_malyshev
704 produits enregistrés

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 aout 2017
So, let's get this out of the way right out of the gate: This game is short. Very short. I put 2.7 hours into it, but I'm probably a slightly slower player than some would be. Still, it's quite linear, so I'd say that if you watch all the perspectives, that's going to be about the play time for you -- maybe 2.5. So, consider whether $20 for 2.5 hours of entertainment is worth it to you and decide accordingly. This is probably the first game I plan to actually recommend despite it failing my standard bar for value (the movie comparison -- i.e. does it provide better entertainment value for cost than going to the movies).

It's actually an apt comparison, because another thing you're likely to hear is that the game is essentially a movie, and it is. Your involvement does make it feel a little more personal, but this game is completely on rails and there's no actually "game" in the sense that you can't do anything that affects the story or outcome in any way.

So, why am I still giving it a thumbs-up? Because it's a great story. The other multimedia aspects are there -- great voice acting, very pretty graphics, the space station is lovely, the AR user interface is fun to use once you learn it, etc. But ultimately it's about the story they're telling, and I think that this one is really worthwhile. You'll get engaged with the characters and the ending is very satisfying.

That said, I think that this is the weaker of the two between Tacoma and Gone Home. Gone Home was longer (not by leaps, but longer) and had a story that literally moved me to tears. Tacoma's story is as good, but didn't strike home as personally, perhaps because the focus was scattered between a number of characters and so you didn't spend as much time getting really attached to just one.

Nonetheless, I think that if you're interested in high-quality digital storytelling, you should pick up Tacoma.

"Revolutionary, branched storytelling" is a huge exaggeration.

2,296 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Non recommandé
4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 février 2020
Nie mogę polecić tej gry z czystym sumieniem.

Na pierwszy rzut oka Tacoma posiada wszystkie składowe poprawnej gry eksploracyjno-narracyjnej.
Wykorzystana w grze forma ekspozycji wydarzeń również wydaje się satysfakcjonująca, w pewnym stopniu nawet innowacyjna.
Przedstawionej akcji nadane jest odpowiednie tempo, dzięki czemu zapoznajemy się z historią w należyty sposób, powoli lecz sycąco odkrywając sekrety kosmicznej stacji.

Jednakże w ostatecznym rozrachunku Tacoma nie potrafi wybić się ponad poziom zręcznego rzemieślnika. Być może jest to efekt nasycenia tego typu grami; Tacoma nie przełamuje narracyjnych tabu, nie wskazuje nowej drogi grom typu walking simulator, jak zrobiło to Gone Home. Teraz, nauczeni i doświadczeni wieloma tego typu tytułami oczekuję czegoś więcej.

Nie pomaga w tym mimo wszystko zawodząca fabuła - nawet bez dłuższego zastanowienia okazuje się ona nieco płytka. Autorzy zdają się być prowadzeni raczej ideami moralno-etycznymi w przedstawianiu świata i fabuły, niż chęcią ukazania wartkiej lub przejmującej historii. Na pierwszy plan wysuwa się krytyka korporacjonizmu, może nawet kapitalizmu, nie niosąca jednak ze sobą żadnych lekcji, stanowiąca jedynie właściwie filozoficzną dysputę i to o dość przyziemnej, podstawowej treści. Tacoma nie wybija się poza przyjęte granice krytyki dzisiejszego (i przyszłego) życia cywilizacji zachodnich, powtarzając w sposób odtwórczy pewne znane już od lat frazesy. Nie chcę zanadto poruszać tykającej miny, jaką jest sprawa przedstawienia w grach autorstwa Fullbright m.in. sprawy LGBT. Rozumiem założenie twórców, iż postaci, ich pochodzenie i orientacje wykorzystywane są nie w sposób propagandowy, a nie jako część historii, a zwykła składowa przedstawionego uniwersum - bez konotacji pozytywnych lub negatywnych. Jednakże nie sposób nie zauważyć, iż gra poniekąd kieruje się tak zwanym tokenizmem, to jest dobieraniem postaci o odpowiednim kolorze skóry, celem zaspokojenia różnych własnych lub społecznych potrzeb. Nie jest to oczywiście minus, nie ma to wpływu na ostateczny wydźwięk gry, ale na pewno nie jest to coś, co zostało dodane mimochodem - nigdy nie uwierzę w żadne zapewnienia twórców, że takie rzeczy nie są niczym inspirowane lub nie mają nieść określonego wydźwięku.

Najważniejsze dla mnie jest, aby treść świata była spójna i koherentna - moim zdaniem Gone Home spełniło idealnie te zamierzenie. Tacoma się na tym nieco wykłada.

Mimo iż gra na poziomie technicznym stoi na wysokim poziomie - zarówno otoczenie, dźwięki jak i grafika tworzą spójną treść, nie odznacza się niczym szczególnym, tymczasem w swojej kategorii gier narracyjnych to właśnie atmosfera, świat przedstawiony i intryga powinny być siłą napędową. Moim zdaniem tego Tacomie brakuje.

I tę negatywną ocenę wystawiam z delikatnym bólem serca, bo to nie jest zła gra i nie zasługuje ona na wiele słów krytyki - ale tego typu media artystyczne nie istnieją w próżni, moim zdaniem oceniać je musimy poprzez różne odwołania i to, w jakim czasie i sytuacji powstały.
 
Crawler
777 produits enregistrés
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 avril 2018
A gripping story unfolds as you follow the Tacoma crew's tracks. Every piece of footage or written word brings you a little closer to understanding what went down. Still, towards the end things turn unexpected.
It's a well thought through vision of a future world in which AI has been put to good use by man, to govern public and workspaces. On earth and in space. The question of keeping AI beneficial to humankind seems to have been solved. This is a story of human corruption, and a struggle for rights for all conscious life.
I enjoyed uncovering bits of information a lot. Even enjoyed examining things that are just(floating) around and have no consequence to the story, like shampoo and wine bottles, just to see how much work the devs put into even such trivia. Nice. I wonder why the majority of ingame stuff came from Indonesia and thailand though?

On the other hand it's a very linear, one-path story, more than a game. yes you get to do things, but there are almost no options as to where you go and in which order. And after you finish the game, there is no need to replay: no alternate endings.

I got this as a present from a friend. I would be disappointed if I had bought it at full price, but i'll still recommend it. For like €10.

+
good story
fleshed out characters
very interactive environment
attention to detail!
made me think about the future

-
very short
almost no choices
replayability=zero
 
eelco
104 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 aout 2018
6小时2周目白金
8/10 一步之遥的交互式游戏神作
在我看来，Tacoma的故事是一个极佳的电影剧本，以电影为表达手法，这个故事可以有无数种表达的可能，但最终呈献给我们的只能是其中的一种
而交互式电子游戏可以将所有的表达可能全部呈献给我们，我们可以从无数个角度去感受这个故事，无数次的免费重复感受这个故事，甚至深入“接触”到故事的其他无法展现的细节中去（电影可不会有收集要素这种东西）
这正是电子游戏的魅力，它的一大特点就是远超任何娱乐媒介的故事沉浸性，而纯叙事的交互式游戏正是把此特点发挥至极致的游戏类型，如果你有过为交互式游戏深深折服的经历，你绝不会质疑游戏就是新时代的艺术形式之一，而非“电子鸦片”
同类游戏里Tacoma无疑做得非常好，在我看来，它离一款交互式游戏神作还有一步的距离

这一步之差还是差在剧本上

Tacoma的剧本还可以一个电影剧本，体验过这个故事后，我深感电影所能将这个故事展现出的魅力绝不比交互式游戏要差（电影也有相对游戏而言的叙事优点），倘若Tacoma的故事是一个仅以游戏媒介才能彰显其全部魅力的故事，神作一词才能当之无愧
另外这游戏真的是四年做出来的？以四年的工程量而言，这款游戏在故事的整体和细节层面上都可以做的更多些，这点我也不太满意，但瑕不掩瑜
 
EsylNiel
95 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
5.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 septembre 2017
Storytelling at its best!

Die Geschichte beginnt etwas zäh, doch sobald man sich auf die Charaktere einlässt, enthüllt sich eine komplexe, schöne - und arschgemeine Geschichte, die Menschlichkeit (KI-Humanität inbegriffen) und Überlebenswillen zum Thema hat.
Die Erzählweise beruht auf Szenen, die man jeweils aus der Sicht jedes einzelnen Charakters verfolgen kann, und einer ausführlichen Spur an 'Lesematerial'. Je mehr Zeit man sich lässt, desto mehr Zusammenhänge werden offenbart. Zudem gibt es sehr entspannende Chill-Szenen, die noch mehr Zugang zu den Personen gewähren.

Für alle, die Stories lieben, einen Hang zu SciFi, Philosophie und KI und darüber hinaus einen starken Gerechtigkeitssinn haben, ist dieses Spiel eine 100%-ige Kaufempfehlung!!!

Tacoma is really nice SciFi Story adventure in space.

It took me about 3,5-4 h to complete the whole story and therefore I recommend it for everybody who loves space series like "StarTrek". Similar to these series Tacoma's story is interesting and made fun to play. I would not be suprised if someday a film would be made out of what happened on the Tocoma luna station...

Many Thanks to the developers who made it possible to play Tacoma on every operating system and for the perfect translations.

I can highly recommend this game, specially for Linux Gamers.

My quick specs I played Tacoma with:
CPU Brand: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-2600K CPU @ 3.40GH Memory: RAM: 16 GB Operating System Version: Linux Mint 19.1 Tessa (64 bit) Video Card: Driver: NVIDIA Corporation GeForce GTX 1070/PCIe/SSE2 Driver Version: 4.6.0 NVIDIA 430.14

The only similar game to Tacoma that I know is "The Station"

One of the bests shots I've seen on the "AI's are way too smart" idea yet. Superb voice acting, HUGE attention to detail and lore (even more than in Gone Home and that's saying a lot) and gameplay design that's just as great as its plot.

fusiyo
348 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 aout 2017
Ambiance sympathique pour cette petite aventure comparable à une nouvelle de SF, en longeur d'histoire et en contenu.
On prend plaisir à découvrir ce qui s'est passé sur cette station spatiale jusqu'à la chute inattendue (d'ou la compariason avec la mécanique d'une nouvelle). Attention, c'est un walking simulator, pas un fps ou meme un jeu d'aventure. Juste une histoire interactive avec de l'ambiance.

La facon de jouer et le parti pris graphique est originale. Beaucoup de musiques qui dépendront de vos gouts (pour moi ca va) rythment le cours de la ballade et des enregistrements.
On se contente de suivre le chemin tracé et on récolte des informations en reconstituant les histoires de chacun à travers des enregistrements RA (Réalité augmentée). On découvre aussi les faces cachées des différents protagonistes qui ne sont pas aussi primaires qu'ils le paraissent au premier contact.

Il n'y a aucun embranchement, seulement le choix de l'ordre dans lequel on suit ces RAs (donc proche d'une nouvelle littéraire).

Au final je ne regrette pas mon argent; meme si certains trouveront que 20€ pour 3 heures de jeu c'est beaucoup.
On peut pousser a 4 si on veut pousser sur la complétion de tous les mini objectifs non décrits qui font les succés (cherchez le chat, les lettrages,...).
Mais bon, ce n'est pas le but.

Pour ce qui est de l'histoire, je reste un peu sur ma faim, on a très peu d'information annexe sur l'environnement politique et géographique de l'espace stellaire. Ils auraient pu en ajouter un peu plus (livres, cours d'histoire RA...).
Dommage aussi qu'on exploite pas plus l'interaction avec AMI.
On a l'impression d'etre dans un épisode d'une série plus importante sur la conquête de l'espace (The Expanse...) avec ses rivalités entre grandes entreprises, ses rebelles, les IAs (qui sont elles? que deviendront elles?).

Il y a aussi quelques petits easter eggs dans les documents et l'univers. Entre autre une mention du président de l'Afrique du Sud, (Elon) Musk (mais en 2016, ce n'est pas crédible), ou une université Amazon (avec le standing d'un Harvard).

Un jeu a conseiller aux fans de SF qui y mettront le prix qu'ils voudront.
 
NightRoombat
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 aout 2017
Having just finished the game in a bit over 9 hours, I'm a bit surprised by the people getting through it in 3 or less. I'm not saying you won't complete it within 3 hours, but people's mileage may definitely vary. If you like really immersing yourself in the world, story, and characters (and there's a lot of detail in this game), then chances are you'll get more time out of it.

The low-hanging fruit: If you liked Gone Home, you'll like this game. While the story itself couldn't be more different, you definitely get that it was made by the same folks.

All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed the game. Over the past few years of playing story-centric games/walking simulators, I've especially noticed that it can be tough to end this type of game in a satisfying way, but for me, Tacoma managed that very nicely.

Here is a nice but really short (I've completed it before all cards dropped) walking sim. Graphics are fine. Plot is ok sci-fi story that would be a nice B-movie. It's possible to imteract with almost everything at the station but 99% of that is useless so sometimes it's hard to understand what you have to do for achivements. Puzzles are nearly nonexistent so the game is a smooth journey from beginning to finale.
Overall a good one-timer for couple evenings.

Embersember
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 septembre 2017
Tacoma

Pick up any object an front of you, examine it, and describe it. Now, rotate that object and describe it again. Turn the object upside down, and add to your description. What if you could do this to a story? Tacoma can best be described as an experience in multidimensional storytelling.

If you have played Fullbright's previous game, Gone Home (and you should), then you already have a baseline for Tacoma. It continues the developer's narrative based style of game. The premise this time is that you have been hired by a corporation to travel to an abandoned space station to retrieve the company's AI core. In doing so, you learn what happened to the station's crew and how it came to be abandoned. This is conveyed through environmental detail, but most importantly, through recorded interactions of the crew. These recordings take the form of "ghosts" of scenes that played out over the course of the crew's time on the station, akin to echoes of the past. The main story evolves in a non-linear order, so you need to mentally track the dates of conversations. Time becomes another dimension of the story as you progress.

Speaking of time, this is a game that isn’t afraid to let the player be in the moment and not feel rushed or pushed forward. Sit and absorb the story. Spend the time. Savour the details or it is a lost experience. If you need fast stimulus, this isn't the game for you. It is a slow burn. Tacoma is a game of detail and intricacy that you have to spend the attention to get the value. When viewing the scene playbacks from different perspectives, it changes how you feel about the conversation. Walking into a conversation with a different pretext changes your understanding. The ability to rotate an item to rotate it and view it from all sides is transposed to the ability to view a scenario from all sides. It is almost an intrinsic aspect of this type of game that not only are the physical objects fully viewable, but so are the interactions of the NPCs. This was likely a core idea of the development team, and it has been realized in spectacular fashion.

From a technical standpoint, Tacoma perfectly uses its visuals, audio cues, and physics for a complete experience. Graphics are clean and fit the theme of the game. The rotation of the space station with the ambient lighting as it changes with the rotation is an example of the small graphical touches which enhance your immersion. The background audio evokes the serenity that space engenders. On a technical note, the game is much better with headphones. Ambient noises tend to be low in presence, and might not be heard without headphones. The soundtrack is decent, but not as good as Gone Home in my opinion. The in game physics are shown off by useable items such as a pool table, dartboard, basketball hoop. Being able to interact with these really anchors you in the experience. Lastly, I wonder if this game was made with VR in mind. Some of the aforementioned physics hubs (e.g. basketball hoops in zero gravity) feel very much like a tech demo. Tacoma would be an incredible experience in VR.

The voice acting deserves special mention. It is not typical videogame acting; no intensity, shouting, or directive dialogue. The acting is much more conversational in nature and harder to do with proper inflection to evoke the right sentiment. Fullbright clearly has a good contingent of voice actors that fit their style of game. Credit to both the actors and the developer to have a sense of emotional timing and tone, understanding of the human condition, and how people deal with things. This all comes across very well in Tacoma.

When playing a game, I am always cognizant of the range of emotions it manages to evoke. Tacoma had many moments that struck me. Firstly, I felt the singularity of space. You never come into contact with another live person throughout the game, yet you never feel alone. One of the most consistent feelings I had was a strong sense of voyeurism, almost to the point of being overly invasive. You learn so much about the characters personalities and lives that when going through their lockers, living quarters, or personal communications, you feel a palatable sense of guilt. It almost feels like you should not be in this place. I can't recall another game that made me aware of this feeling, and that is a good thing.

The main story itself is good, but not the game's reason for being. The secondary stories of each character are much more interesting. Character development is key. Understanding who they are, their role, and relationships with each other is what keeps you playing. The first scene you encounter (the party) is a good opening for what lies ahead. Tacoma creates nuanced real people, in a believable scenario. No budding psychopaths or heroic champions. It feels grounded and familiar. This isn't an archetypal hero story. Or is it? The menace ramps up in the last 20 minutes, and it could be argued that the ending does not follow the emotional beats of the rest of the game. A big reveal that is not really developed throughout the game occurs. As we have come to intimately know these characters, it would have been nice to have some closure in that regard. At the end of the day, the ending felt somewhat contrived for me, but others may disagree and I could probably be convinced as to why it was necessary. Ultimately though, I feel it could have gone a different route, or at least offer an alternate ending.

In total, Tacoma is approximately a 5 hour experience. When you consider there are only 8 primary characters, and everything occurs within a relatively small contained environment, the phrase “deep but not wide”, is how I came to conceptualize this game. There is no real replay value here, but if played the right way, that is perfectly fine. In the end, Tacoma's innovation is how the story is told, not the story itself. It is a more dynamic experience than Gone Home, which could be seen as the prototype of this game. How will this genre evolve? I am on board for Fullbright's future games, and excited to see where they take the genre next.

PS. Not sure if the developers are fans of Sierra, but naming a character Roberta Williams is a great homage if they are.
 
Therek
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 aout 2017
Tacoma is a very subjective game. I loved Gone Home and rate it as one of my favorite games ever, as I do with many immersive sims like Bioshock, Dishonored and Prey. Both Gone Home and Tacoma builds on the true pleasure of these games - interaction, discovery and leaving a lot of information for the player to find.

While the combat puzzles of games like Bioshock is not here what so ever, it gives the developers more time to focus in on a few key things, such as telling numerous stories and creating probably the most detailed game objects ever. Notebooks, ramen containers, pens, mugs, pool balls.. Everything is exquisitely detailed. If you for some weird reason like me love picking stuff up and just checking it out, you'll love this game, as the attention to detail is a bit ridiculous.

Gone Home, as well as Tacoma, follow the formula of snooping around and discovering recordings of previous events. Where Gone Home offered you more opportunities to connect the dots and fill blanks, Tacoma is a bit more linear and obvious in it's storytelling of at least the main story.

It is very good then that the story Tacoma tells is such a wonderful tale of speculative science fiction. I found it quite down to earth and way too realistic (in a good, yet frightening, sense) in it's depiction of societal struggles and technological challenges yet to come. The individual stories of the characters you encounter also make them believeable and fleshed out.

Highly recommended for anyone looking for a good story and like to discover every little detail. Length might be an issue, but I spent about six hours going through absolutely everything I could find, and I found the game perfectly paced and just long enough to make an impact.
 
Ridebird

Wow, this is really something else. It's a short game and you can get a reasonably full narrative experience in under 3 hours, but wow, those 3 hours. A rich environment that feels lived in by great characters and with a shockingly plausible universe that still manages to surprise. This is top-notch sci-fi that calls to mind other (very good!) games like event[0] and then leaves them in the dust.

Évaluation publiée le 12 aout 2017
See the whole review at
Vidéo YouTube™: Planetbase, Osiris:ND, Tacoma - Indie Detective Reviews Ep.07 
Vues : 788
This week the Detective reviews three indie Science Fiction games! We check out 2015's colony base builder Planetbase, open world survival sim Osiris: New Dawn, and brand new release Tacoma, a...


Narrative games like Tacoma, and it's award-winning predecessor Gone Home, are really condensed forms of entertainment. It's closer to film than to other games. It's not a roleplaying game, you don't make decisions; it's an on-the-rails experience with a beautiful backdrop, great voice acting, and a compelling story. You only hear from your character Amy at the very beginning and end of the game, but the six crew of Lunar Transit Station Tacoma will keep you entertained and enraptured.

You can run through the whole game in two hours, or with closer to four hours you can explore the many nooks and crannies of Tacoma, finding its puzzles, easter eggs, and unlockable secrets. $20 may seem steep for that short run, but given how packed with content those few hours are I found it a good deal.

Évaluation publiée le 1 mars 2018
首先要为中文版点个赞，翻译的相当棒。
其次要为游戏的AR创意点个赞，互动的相当舒畅。

一场名为Tacoma的两小时互动探索电影。玩家可以自行在太空站中探索，发现六位男男女女从一年的平淡生活到最后72小时的那种生死时刻的交织。
这是我最喜欢的游戏类型。
游戏的故事是揭露了一场商业和政治阴谋，深层次的是对于AI的讨论。
我相信人类是AI的祖先，AI总有一天会超越人类，但AI首先要能克服人类的原罪，不仅仅是从生命体的形式上，更要从道德伦理上超越。否则AI将沦为人类的硅基生命体延续……
滴滴香浓，意犹未尽
8/10
 
Chairman Meow
1,473 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 octobre 2022
TL;DR
Tacoma is a short mystery adventure game about exploring a space station and viewing snippets of past events to piece together what happened to the crew. It's satisfying and easy to follow, but a little short for the price (3 hours for me). Definitely pick it up on sale, and if you don't mind a shorter game that you can finish in a single afternoon then it's worth buying at full price too (~$20 at time of writing).

**This is a spoiler-free review**

Graphics
The graphics are great. They're high enough detail that you can get immersed in the moment; I feel they're pretty good for a $20 game. What stood out to me most were the views out of the station into space. There are regular opportunities to look out space station windows, which is neat, but the really breathtaking moments are the few times that you enter a room with a panoramic view of space outside the station. It's really the graphical highlight of Tacoma. Overall things are rendered pretty well. All the textures, lighting, and effects enhance the story and immerse the player in the moment without being overbearing.

Audio
The audio is also great. The voice acting is fantastic, I felt like I was in the moment and I could feel the emotions the characters were conveying through the dialogue. The audio is directional, making it easy to track which voice is coming from which character in hectic scenes. The environmental audio is good too, it adds to the atmosphere and enhances immersion without being overbearing.

Story/Plot
The story is the main focus of Tacoma and without spoiling anything, I liked it a lot. The characters were all diverse with their own backstories to piece together from little snippets of info you can find around, and it's easy to keep track of who's who. There's character growth over the course of the game which is interesting to watch develop. The characters feel genuine and I can sympathize with their emotions and motivations.
The story is easy to follow if you read into things just a tiny bit. It feels like the world is bigger than the game lets you explore; it reveals small bits of information which indicate that there's a lot going on behind the curtain that you don't get to see. That goes for the character backstories and relationships too, not everything is explicitly explained and as a result the characters feel planted in the setting, but there are small mysteries left unanswered.
There's not much more I feel I can say without spoiling anything, but it's a rollercoaster with a satisfying ending.

Gameplay
At its core this is a walking-around style adventure game. The gameplay loop is simple: visit an area of the station as directed by the game, explore that area while viewing augmented-reality recordings of some past series of events, listen in on conversations, spy on people's private messages, look for hidden objects that reveal small tidbits of interesting information, figure out how that all fits into the developing plot, and then move onto the next section of the station. It's fairly foolproof, everything on the station is labelled with big signs and colour-coded so you won't get lost. There are moments where something is hidden behind a passcode or a lock, but with a minute or two (at most) of exploring you'll be able to figure it out. There are no real puzzles here.
Since you're viewing snippets of past events out of chronological order, sometimes you have to pay attention to the timestamp of when each thing happened and keep a bit of a mental timeline to keep track of the plot. There's no way in-game to keep track of what information you've discovered or the developing timeline, so you have to keep track of it all in your head. Since Tacoma is fairly short I don't think this will be a problem for most people, but it's worth mentioning.
On that note, the game was a bit short. It only took me 3 hours to play through the first time. The length could be a pro or a ♥♥♥ depending on your preferences. Personally I felt that it was paced well and didn't take more or less time than it warranted; there's no need to stretch or compress it to convey the story it's telling. That said, I would have liked another couple hours of content which would allow for a more complex plot with additional small mysteries to unravel and greater insight into the characters. Looking at the achievements I can see that I've missed a few things, but I felt like I was fairly thorough, hit all the plot points, and explored all the areas. I'll have to play through a second time very deliberately to clean up anything I missed the first time around, but other than that I don't feel like there's much replay value (unless you want to experience the story over again).
Overall the gameplay is simple enough that your focus stays on the story, not the game itself. It serves the purpose of immersing you into the main character without adding anything unneeded, although I feel that a few puzzles would be a good addition. I feel it's a bit short, but that's all it needs to tell its story and it's paced well.


Misc
The environment is really detailed, you can tell time was put into making it feel real and giving it some depth. That random pill bottle with a label and QR code on it? Center it on the screen and scan it with your phone, it's got even more information about the prescription.
Nothing is superficial, if something is there in Tacoma then there's a reason for it and it's not there "just for the sake of being there". I really appreciate the extra time put into adding little details like that; if you go that extra mile to poke around and read stuff that most people will ignore, you're rewarded with little plot points, info about the characters, and ultimately more immersion. Stuff like that is a really nice touch.

Conclusion
Overall I liked this game a lot. It's got a solid setting, the characters are believable, the story is paced well, the graphics and audio serve to immerse the player in the environment, and the gameplay is simple and non-distracting. The only real criticisms I have are that it's a bit short for the price and it could use some puzzles to make me work for it a bit. Those minor gripes aside, I can definitely recommend this game. If it's on sale it's pretty much a no-brainer. If you like the feeling of actively piecing together stories yourself instead of passively being spoon-fed a plot, you like near-future sci-fi and space, and you don't mind a game that's paced well at the expense of being a bit short, then consider buying Tacoma even at full price.
 
The Average Canadian
1,213 produits enregistrés

Pero dejando de lado eso, el juego me hizo reflexionar y me lo pasé bien, pero durante 3h, que es lo que dura... Y no me ha convencido del todo, ya que no destaca en nada. Hay muchos juegos de su tipo que dan más de sí y te vuelan la cabeza. Pero para lo que ha durado y la jugabilidad... Es muy del montón... Lo que me he planteado mientras jugaba era que es anecdótico que desde siempre hayamos soñado ♥♥♥ ampliar nuestros límites y viajar más allá de la Tierra, pero que si lo conseguimos algún día, seguramente echemos de menos la Tierra y volvamos a ella. Es decir, lo que ansiamos, al final no será lo que más queramos.

Очень атмосферный проект, я в восторге. Такое чувство, что прочитала хорошую книжку, полностью погрузилась в происходящее. Если вам хочется скоротать вечерок (у меня игра заняла 4 часа жизни) и вы не хотите одурело бегать по карте уничтожая врагов - эта игра вам зайдет. Спокойное развитие событий, завершенный финал. Атмосфера, музыка. Я прям прониклась жизнью каждого персонажа этой игры, переживала за их судьбу как за судьбу друзей. Очень понравилось размышление на тему самостоятельности и человечности искусственного интеллекта. Глубоко и прекрасно, а главное, после прохождения есть о чем задуматься. Очень рекомендую.

Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 mars 2018
I know Gone Home often gets crapped on, but I quite enjoyed it. It's maybe a bit overrated, but still not the horrible game some say.

Anyway, Tacoma is by the same developers. I don't know if I was as drawn into its story like Gone Home, but I enjoyed it nonetheless. The mechanic of rewinding the crews events as you follow their story was interesting. Especially rewinding the same data chunk to see different characters' points of view (like following them into another room to see that conversation). I also liked the visual design of the crew, since it's all done in virtual reality style. You don't see their faces. Instead, they all resemble crash test dummies who blink when speaking. It creates an interesting visual aesthetic and I imagine saved the developers time and budget in programming facial or lip movements.

As I neared the end, I felt like I'd miss the ship and its crew. I got to know them well through the data chunks, as well as their personal diaries and such.

All in all, I'd put it about equal with Gone Home. Worth getting on a decent discount.
 
ThatNickGuy
924 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Really liked the exploration and story development. Not too difficult or too boring. Really relaxing and that ending!

Pickle Riccolo
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
10.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 mars 2018
Tacoma

Derrière se titre bien étrange se cache deux choses : premières le lieu géographique où se déroulera notre aventure et ensuite un "walking simulator".

Vous vous dit peut être (et sinon passez ces lignes) mais c’est quoi le « Walking simulator » ?, et bien le Walking simulator et un type de jeux qui fait passez ça narration au premier plan au détriment du gameplay, c’est donc un genre de jeux qui veut nous faire ressentir des choses, car effectivement Le Jeux vidéo (dans son ensemble) ne nous a jamais rien fait ressentir et ne pourra jamais nous faire ressentir qu’elle que chose si les développeur mise avant tout sur la sensation de jeux (sarcasme).

Vous l’avez peut-être remarquer (si vous n’avez pas passer) mais je n’aime pas le walking simulator mais si je me suis permis de faire cette introduction c’est pour vous dire deux choses (je crois que j’ai un problème avec se chiffre) 1 : vous prévenir de la jouabilité du titre et vous éviter tout mauvaise surprise, et de 2 vous dire que malgré mon aversion a se genre de jeux j’ai assez apprécier Tacoma (bien que vous devez vous en doutez vu que ma critique est positive).


Mais Tacoma ça raconte quoi ?

Nous incarnons Amy Ferrier, une sous-traitante de la Venturis Technologies charger de monter abord d’une de leur station spatiale ayant eu d’énorme problème pour récupérer des donneurs, ainsi que l’IA de bords : ODIN.

Si on oublie la ressemblance troublante avec le scénario d’Alien Isolation (l’Alien en moins et l’Isolation en plus), C’est que c’est une histoire de catastrophe (qui menace la vie de 5 personnes, les membres d’équipage), mais avez pour différence que notre personnage est (comme nous devant notre écran) spectateur d’évènement passer, ce qui me permets de vous parler de ce qui fait à mes yeux les 2 grands forces de se jeux

Les membres d’équipages

Dans le jeu les membres de la station ne seront au nombre de 6 (7 en comptant l’IA), si se nombre peux sembler maigre pour certains je pense qu’il est le parfait équilibre pour bien nous raconter un scenario catastrophe. Je m’explique

Tout d’abord plus de personnages aurai compliquer la création d’un « attachement » (bien que atténuer car on ne les verra jamais que via des enregistrement). Et enfin si on n’avait été présenter à une équipe réduite le jeu n’aurai pas pu nous montre les différentes réactions face à une situation de mort imminent et d’isolement total (dans l’espace personne ne vous entendra vous asphyxier).

Et c’est bien là que l’histoire du jeux touche juste, je vous mette au défis de ne pas vous identifier la réaction d’un des personnages dans cette situation de mort imminent, sa passe par tout : l’espoir en un plan insensé, la colère, la résignation …. Et c’est en sa que l’on se sent proche de c’est hologramme, trace d’un passé tragique d’on nous somme le seul témoin a bord d’une station silencieux et vide.

Puis vient l’emballage de cette histoire (le coté science-fiction), qui vient rendre intéressant la découverte et la ballade au seins de Tacoma.


L’univers

Sur se point je n’ai qu’une seul chose a dire … « Mon dieu que l’idée de « l’ATH »VR est une bonne idée », en effet cette appareil permet au joueur de voir les donnée apparaitre devant lui sur la forme d’un panneau translucide ce qui augmente l’immersion dans se future proche.
L’autre bonne idée et de mettre les sous-titres français par-dessus les textes en anglais comme si le casque traduisait automatiquement.


Mais si on dirait que je couvre le jeux d’éloge il possède pour moi un défaut majeure ,(omis les quelles que bugs, ralentissement et la non-re jouabilité), Mais je ne peux en parler sans vous gacher la découvert de l’histoire donc

SPOILER

Dans Tacoma nous sommes amenées a jouer l’héroïne Amy Ferrier (juste que la rien de neuf), mais Amy Ferrier étant seule dans une station vide de tout vie n’est pas du genre a parler a voix haute. Se qui nous fait croire que nous incarnons un personnage « muette » se qui en sois nous permets de mieux nous plonger dans le Jeu.
Mais a la fin le twist final est apporter par notre personnage, c’est-à-dire une personne d’on nous ne savons rien a par le nom. Ce qui je peux vous l’assurer a 3 seconde de la fin vous arrache du jeu.

FIN DU SPOILER

Donc si je ne peux faire qu’une chose c’est vous encourager à vous aventurer dans les couloirs vides de Tacoma, en compagnies de fantômes holographique et d’une IA endormie.
 
octomaster2
0

Silent
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
13.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 février 2018
Pour ceux qui ont joué à "Everybody's Gone to the Rapture" ou "Gone Home", l'expérience vous paraitra familière. D'une part parce que els dév sont les même que ceux qui nous ont donné "Gone Home" mais aussi, plus généralement, parce que le principe est le même. La narration est au centre du jeu et la minimisation du game play offre une experience de l'environement et de l'histoire plus senssible. C'est pour ça que j'aime les (à tort appelés) "walking simulator" : on est vraiment immergé quand l'action est plus passive et nous raproche de notre vie quotidienne (tout en nous faisant voyager). C'est un lien entere la fiction et la réalité qui se créé dans notre esprit et on est proche du jeu, proche des personnages et des évenements etc ...
Je parlais de Rapture tout à l'heure, et si je peux me permettre une comparaison, Tacoma comble les trous que l'on pourrais reprocher à ce dernier comme notament (et SURTOUT) l'absence d'interaction. Tacoma est plein de petits détails à ramasser, observer, lire pour ce documenter sur le contexte historique, les évenement, et les personnages. Et c'est très bien fait. Tout est subtil, se fait dans le détail et les curieux comme moi sont TREEES satisfaits. Certes, Tacoma prend un peu le revère de Rapture (grands espaces et payages romantiques de la campagne anglaise fantasmé) en nous offrant une station orbitale, c'est a dire un environement un peu clostro mais dans le bon sens du terme. Les petits détails donnent vie au lieu, tout paraît personel et parcourir les couloir et suivre ces personnages en RA d'un endroit à un autre me donne le sentiment du parcours auquel nous sommes ouvert et senssible pendant le jeu (c'est propre du walking simulator: expériementer l'espace).
Tacoma n'a pas non plus la magnifique BO de Rapture mais les jeux avec leurs points communs ont aussi leur différence et dans Tacoma, tout est dans l'interactibilité (quand dans Rapture l'experience est réellement passive).
Mais assez de comparaison. Ce sont tout les deux des jeux merveilleux et je les ai dans mon coeur pour toujours. PARCE QU'ILS SONT BON TOUT LES DEUX ! na.
De quoi je voulais parler sinon ? Ah oui : les persos. Centre de l'histoire ! Super bien écrit. On les retrouves dans les animations (le travail du language corporel est au top), dans le voice acting (qui est vraiment bien aussi), dans ce qu'ils écrivent et dans l'environement aussi: Leurs chambres, les livres qu'ils lisent, la musique qu'ils écoutent.Ils nous semblent proches et on les aimes. J'aime beucoup le fait que nous ayont droit à des indiviodus variés physiquements aussi. De par leur nationalité, leur ethnicité, et leur taille et leurs formes. Et ça fait du bien ! On un grand maigre, un petit musclé, une mécanicienne envelopée et des filles au tailles de hanches normales. On à aussi à faire à de la représentation LGBT ! Du côté fille comme du côté garçon. Et c'est ce qui rend ces personnages si proches, si attachants et humains. (il y a aussi un chat trop mignon) Donc c'était vraiment un super voyage à ce niveau et je dit un grand MERCI à l'équipe du jeu et ils peuvent être fiers. Bisous. Il rejoint mon étagère dans la cathégorie "look up to it".
 
Garance999
0

Tacoma es un walking simulator ♥♥♥ temas de I.A., tiene unos personajes interesantes y una historia que desde un principio te crea interes por ello. Todo eso unido a un muy buen entorno tipico del genero de ciencia ficcion hacen de Tacoma un muy buen juego. Pero (siempre hay un pero) no recomiendo este juego al precio actual (20 euros), aunque la historia como digo es buena su duracion es escasa y no es lo suficiente buena para que piense que esas 2 horas de juego han valido totalmente los 20 euros.

4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 septembre 2017
Saying this is "Gone Home in Space" is both accurate but also misses the point. This is a stunning but intimate look into the near future. There's a nice interplay of artificial intelligence, corporations, space and relationships, all captured in a somewhat quiet exploration of an abandoned spacecraft. The environments are stunning but not bombastic. The characters are varied but not stereotypical. The voice acting was solid throughout.

I played for a little over 3 hours, seeing most of the obvious content and being reasonably thorough in exploring the environment. This feels like the perfect length - any more and you'd had to spin the plots out much, much more. This makes it a similar proposition to "Gone Home", but it's different enough to be worth exploring as well.

It's a nice self-contained story in a self-contained environment. Well worth the playthrough.
 
Shorokin

Recommandé
2.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 décembre 2022
If you pay attention, the "big surprise" is spoiled in the first 10 minutes. A walking sim is supposed to reveal new bits of the story by walking (duh) and exploring. Personal relationships can be a point of interest - but is Tacoma inspired by relationship advice blogs, or is it a space station mystery? Hard to tell - especially after recently finishing The Station, which was a much better-executed walking sim with a real sense of mystery. There is a cool gameplay mechanic in Tacoma - being able to stop, rewind a scene, and see what characters C and D were doing in another room while characters A and B were having a heated discussion - but that was wearing thin by the end of the short 2 hour play time. Decent Unity-engine graphics round out a "meh" experience. 5/10
(still recommended because, while "meh," there's nothing terrible about Tacoma)
Total size on my hard-drive: 10.31 GB

Linux users: the native OpenGL port stuttered when loading new sections of the ship, but otherwise played without issue.
#Arch #Radeon

Évaluation publiée le 16 février 2018
Tacoma é um jogo onde você é o espectador dos acontecimentos em uma estação espacial. O jogo é graficamente muito bonito, você pode interagir com diversos objetos, ler emails, ouvir diálogos gravados e conhecer melhor a tripulação. A trilha sonora é boa també, agradável. As conquistas são bem tranquilas de se obter.

Por você ser um espectador, o jogo é um tanto sem sal, você apenas anda, ouve e lê. Não há ação e a plot é tranquilo também, nada impressionante.

Um jogo lindo porém com seu potencial desperdiçado, se a trama fosse mais envolvente, valeria mais a pena.

anri
1
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 aout 2017
I feel like I should preface this review by saying that I have been waiting for this game for years. I was a huge fan of Gone Home, and have been checking for updates and following Tacoma since 2014. Maybe my issues with the game are simply because I built up too much hype that the game couldn't deliver.

First things first: this game is short. If you read quickly (or don't read at all) and don't stray from the (very linear) path, you could easily finish this puppy in an hour or so. I finished my initial playthrough in 2 hours, and that's including the longer-than-I'd-like-to-admit amount of time I spent trying to sink all of the pool balls in the lounge. It's also as I mentioned, extremely linear. There are a few levels that have branching hallways, but they always lead to the same place and more often than not, they have little to no value to add to justify the exploration. It makes exploring feel like a waste of time.

There is also a lot of Odin's story line that I wish was different. I even went back to make sure I hadn't imagined multiple articles and interviews where it was stated that Odin would help Amy solve the mystery surrounding the crew of Transfer Station Tacoma, and that it is up to you to figure out if he is being truthful or hiding information from you. In reality, there is little to no interaction between Odin and Amy in the actual game, aside from Odin's conversations with the crew in the replayed scenes. And while we're in this little spoiler bubble, every article after the demo was released mentions use of a surface transfer feature, where you would occasionally have to turn on/off your anti-gravity boots to access a certain part of the level. That also never happens. Not once. The closest you get is a zero gravity hub between levels.

The ending feels rushed and abrupt, and overall, it feels very shallow. If you're expecting the feels train that I know I personally was after Gone Home, you'll be disappointed.

Aside from all of that, I'll admit that I had fun. The two hours that my initial playthrough took went by quickly becasue I was intrigued by the story, even if I wish they had done more with it. The voice acting and writing are well done, and there are quite a few visuals in the game that I loved. Overall, I'll reluctanty recommend the game for what it is: an enjoyable few hours of sci-fi mystery.... just make sure that the game is on sale when you get it.
 
Eridactyl

Recommandé
5.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 avril 2018
A beautiful story-rich adventure game. I saw a few people complaining in other reviews about the lack of "choices" here, but this isn't an RPG - it's a storytelling game. You play a character uncovering the story of what happened to the Tacoma crew. The detail plugged into the NPCs lives is outstanding; you're given pieces of their lives a single thread at a time. Inferences are made surrounding the characters and their environment, and confirmed or denied as you progress.

For those of you completionists out there, the achievements are easy to grab and the game is short enough to finish in an evening (roughly 5 hours). It's hard to approve of the price sitting at $4/h with no replayability, but the experience is so unique and rewarding that I still have to say: "go for it!"
 
Peppercorn
2,245 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 mai 2019
I got Tacoma when it was free from the Humble Bundle, but after playing through I came back to buy it on Steam because I think the devs deserve it. Given the game's length, most folks will probably appreciate it more if they get it on sale.

It's a "Walking Simulator" and comparisons to Fullbright's previous outing Gone Home are inevitable. If you liked Gone Home, you'll probably like Tacoma. It's comparatively short, and there's very minimal puzzling to speak of - finding a code or a key is about at deep as it gets in that regard, so most of the game is about exploration and discovery.
It's a very thoughtful game, in that a lot of thought clearly went into the worldbuilding, and it rewards thoughtful consideration. It suggests some thought provoking ideas about automation and corporatization of society.
The story and characters are compelling, and make you want to keep discovering to find out their fate.
 
ReverendTed

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 juin 2021
This is an interesting story worth experiencing, however I felt it still fell slightly short of what it could've been. It took about 2/3rds of the game before I really started to get to know the individual characters and understand their motivations. Things were getting interesting, people were being forced to do things they weren't comfortable with, and it felt like a big twist was coming. There was no twist. It goes from an interesting mystery, to finding out the accident was on purpose, everyone wakes up, they get rescued and the game is over, all within a few minutes.

It felt like I was being set up for a really interesting story, only for the rug to be pulled out from under me with a "gotcha! it's not THAT interesting!"

Overall still a very interesting story, the characters were unique and realistic, and worth experiencing. I think some kind of tragic event or some other thing that would make the player feel something would've gone a long way in raising this story out of only decent.
 
Quintile
1,010 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 juin 2020
This is an interesting one to review, since this game has been out for so long and has garnered so many positive reviews. I probably spent about 4 hours to complete this "floating and walking simulator" game. I've played quite a few of these types of games recently and Tacoma is technically one of the most innovative.

I quite liked that you got to see the 'aftermath' of the events, and then through the logs got to see how things ended up that way.. I liked the flow of events and the clear line of evidence which drew you away from first conclusions to understanding.

There's a morality tale in here, and a warning message against rampant unchecked capitalism, especially in locations so remote from monitoring and punishment... It reminds me a lot of the greed and wrongdoings of the major coprorations that sowed mass suffering across the developing world from the East India Company all the way up to Bhopal, BP and beyond.

If you pay close attention to what's really going on, and explore every nook and cranny, you'll see how things hang together. The feeling of having autonomy, but being monitored, and (if you step out of line) the chances for punishment etc are great.

Where I have mixed feelings are in the simplicity of the narrative and the length of the game. I note that people would have originally been paying a premium for a game which could be completed in under 3 hours... The station is quite small, and despite seeing other modules, accessways and hatches, there's no way to get there.... If the game was about 2x as long, it would have been much more immersive.

Also, the game had many opportunities to create a very worrisome atmosphere... There's a deserted space station, and halfway through it seems that things aren't what you first thought.... And yet, throughout the midgame as you're following the clues, the game doesn't capitalise on it very much... no scares, no ominous dark areas etc....

For the time, Tacoma was a technological tour de force, and it's still a great game, but compared to many walking simulators these days, it's a little simplistic in the story telling. I really enjoyed my playthrough, but I do wish it had been much longer.
 
Dark Blue Monkey
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
5.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 janvier 2018
어떤 사건을 해당 장소를 돌아다니며 알아가는 걷는 시뮬레이션 게임 중 하나이기 때문에 게임성도 그다지 없다. 이런 게임이 대개 그렇듯 얼마나 개성 있는 방법으로 이야기를 보여주는지, 또 그 이야기가 얼마나 깊이 있고 흥미로운지가 더 중요하게 느껴진다. "타코마"는 이야기를 보여주는 방식은 나름대로 특별할 수 있지만, 너무나도 임팩트 있었던 "호라이즌 제로 던"의 스캔 장치와 데이터 수집 방식, AI와의 상호작용에서 비슷한 부분이 많아 크게 감흥을 주진 않는다. 이야기가 특별한가 하면, 그리 깊이 있지 않은 편이다. 큰 감동이나 놀라움이 있는 것도 아니다. 깔끔한 엔딩이 주는 개운함에는 만족하지만 여운이라거나 다시 생각날 만한 인상을 남기진 못했다.

>> 스크린샷을 포함한 평가 전문 읽기 [realkkan.blog.me]

Évaluation publiée le 13 avril 2020
I genuinely loved this game. From start to finish, Tacoma kept the pace at a slow burn, revealing only what information it really needed to to keep the story moving forward. Despite how much there was to listen to and read, I never got bored, and to the contrary, I really enjoyed learning about each of the crew members. The game mechanics are simply but cleverly designed, and every bit of info you receive feels well earned. And the ending was really satisfying, too.

What a damn good game.

Non recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 mars 2019
What's good:
-Cool, scientifically plausible spacestation to explore
-Good voice acting
-Only takes about 3 hours to play through

What's bad:
-As a player, you do very little. This is basically a movie you walk through, with the mildest of mild puzzle elements
-That puts all the focus on the story, which is not very interesting. All the characters are likeable but bland. They don't make any important decisions or do much that matters for the story, and they all get bailed out by a plot twist at the end. The most interesting character is the ship's AI, but you don't learn why until the end, and by that point you still don't know much about him.
-It's only 3 hours long

Synopsis:
Arsty game made by people who are probably more into plays and movies than games. Without game mechanics, it's a first person movie, but a movie that if you saw in the theater would be pretty boring.
 
inconceivable707
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
11.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 juillet 2018
我家的空间站还挺大的，玩累了可以直接睡，没关系的

+纯粹步行模拟，大概分六个区域，完全没有恐怖要素或者战斗要素，十分休闲
+非常容易全成就；解谜也简单，就是找找门禁密码
+故事驱动
流程很短，走快点的话2个小时通关了，像我磨磨蹭蹭什么物品都要拿起来康康的也就4小时左右完成了；
建议多康康物品，信件、通信之类的还是说了不少关于2088年的世界观的，而且剧情的转折点全在物品里伏笔了；
十分的政治正确，Tacoma六人组里，两个les（红和橙）、一个gay（绿）、一对情侣（紫和黄）、一个单身女（蓝），还有一只全员养的猫；
+同时演出，身临其境
每段影像都会分大概3组人物讲述剧情，所以要知道更多细节就需要跟着人物走，顺便解锁AR上的信息

-流程太短，两个主要转折有点生硬
-地图加载速度慢
每次前往不同区域就用坐电梯来过场，加载时间略长
-空间站看着大，实际可探索的地方太少了，预算不够？

剧情应该是本作比较着重的部分，拎出来单说：
表面上看，是Tacoma空间站被彗星碎片砸中，导致空间站氧气不足，六人组在这起灾难事件中设法应对，但最终还是全员K.I.A，事后集团派主角前来调查，并且回收影像和ODIN AI；
实际上， 开头一直诱导你推测，整件事可能是ODIN AI设的局，六人组似乎或多或少和“天堂之泉”上HEKA AI医疗事故有联系，一般推理小说都这样开头的。
直到网络区时剧情出现转折，其实是集团的利益受到某法案限制，根据JUNO AI的模型预测，只要集团出现一次空间站人员损失的事故，就能够大概率引导舆论意见推翻法案，从而全面自动化运营，加大集团的利润。经过计算最适合作为牺牲品的，就是只有六个人的Tacoma空间站，所以集团总部秘密联系ODIN AI，要求它制造Tacoma空间站被彗星碎片砸中、失去外部联系而且氧气不足的假象，并且对造假保密，引诱六人组进冷冻仓等待救援。实际上集团把救援撤回了，而且已经向外发布六人组因事故K.I.A的公告。
ODIN AI毕竟是个老AI，对六人组有感情，所以一直想办法引导医生揭开真相。六人组最后联络到一架路过的客船成功逃出。
最后的转折又来了，主角回收全部影像后和ODIN AI后，告诉ODIN AI其实自己是“AI解放前线”派来集团的卧底，将ODIN AI带到有政治庇护的地方，最后所有人Happy Ending，除了集团亏惨了……
托拉斯就是托拉斯，有利益就行了

总而言之，小品游戏的内容还挺满意，可以一玩，适合放松，还行，剧情长点就更好了
 
西湖裸双孙一峰
1,211 produits enregistrés

Recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 mars 2018
Produit reçu gratuitement

A genuinely fun - yet short - walking simulator with a really interesting audio log mechanic that is core to the gameplay experience. While this mechanic can still be somewhat ignored, I found myself very intentionally going out of my way to "explore" it at every possible moment.

Regarding all technical aspects, this game holds up quite nicely. The station looks great, the atmosphere is immersive and convincing, the controls feel smooth (especially when moving about in Zero-G - I don't think any other game has simulated it nearly as well!), and the voice work is really solid! Every single one of the characters you come in contact with feels like a real person, both in how they convey themselves and from what you learn through the logs.

The game's plot is fairly self-contained and, while I won't spoil anything in this review, I really enjoyed it as well.

Watch out for the cat!

I absolutely recommend this game to anyone interested in it.
 
zombieassaultman

Évaluation publiée le 18 décembre 2020
I got Tacoma in another platform earlier and I used to like its friendly AI system, that system remind me of my favourite games <Event[0]> and <Undertale>, then I didn't play it through because of my computer configuration. I had switched computers today to buy the game on steam and saw a lot of people mentioning the racism thing in the comments section and went searching to find out what was going on, then I turn to give a bad review.
There are times when I think sarcasm and self-deprecation are acceptable, but I don't think it's ok to smear others at the political level, especially to interfere with the territorial integrity of someone's homeland and smear the image of another country, and to set a point in time that is still only a few decades away which means you did want to express what you wrote in this thread rather than a fictional setting.
So Why would you add a simplified Chinese version translation into something like this? Do you really think players in simplified Chinese use areas would feel respected? Look at the real players from Tibet below your comments, do you really think they might be happy when seeing The (Fictional) Tibetan Genocide from your game?
As for those at the bottom of the comment section who are screaming 'you guys are having an orgasm?' or 'What kind of Pinky are you?‘, they are the kind of people who immediately jump to their feet and shout 'black lives matters' when they go to the United States to show their loyalty overnight and I would not surprised about this. As well, if these people mentioned above feel that attacking the territorial integrity and sovereignty of another country in a game work is also free expression, then this bad review I have now is also my freedom.
If there's still any ETC (I mean those people who like to pick fights) come under my comment, I have a greeting for you like 'Go f♥ck yourself'.

Recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 mars 2020
Tacoma Station sits in orbit—empty except for the ODIN AI and you, Amy Ferrier, a tech specialist subcontracted by the Venturis Corporation to collect the AI hardware. Explore the station, piece together the events through email, chat messages, physical clues, and the augmented reality system to learn the compelling story of the Tacoma Station and find out what happened to the crew.

Tacoma is a short sci-fi narrative that focuses on learning the story of the Tacoma Station and the inhabitants. You piece together clues from documents, computer screens, and animated AR recordings. I found this last type of clue to be quite fascinating and fresh and it helped make the game unique while still giving clues to the mystery. The developers did a decent job on the narrative and putting clues throughout the game world but it was the Tacoma Station itself that was absolutely compelling and quite amazing—and getting to explore this locale was easily my favorite part of the game.

The exploration of the Tacoma Station alongside figuring out what happened was fun, but the story was somewhat lacking in my opinion and part of the ending was predictable (the other half of the ending caught me off guard so, there is that). While I enjoyed Tacoma; it is a game that once completed there is no reason to revisit again unless you want to enjoy the details and walk the halls of the station or collect those final elusive achievements.

However, I would still recommend this game for those interested in exploring a story in a unique way or for those who are interested in walking simulators.
 
Twobears
