Recommandé
3.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 juin 2022
Von Hologrammen voller Dystopie, Gefühle und Kapitalismuskritik

Es gibt so einige Szenarien in Filmen oder Videospielen, die meist nichts Gutes ahnen lassen und genauso eines bietet auch Tacoma. Namensgebend ist hier nämlich eine verlassene Raumstation, von der wir im Auftrag des Tech-Unternehmens Venturis eine KI bergen sollen...

In der Rolle von Amy Ferrier befinden wir uns im Jahr 2088 und direkt zu Beginn des Spiels docken wir an unserem Zielort an; es gilt auf drei Ebenen wichtige Daten auf unser mobiles Gerät zu transferieren sowie das Herzstück der KI namens ODIN an uns zu nehmen. Mit dieser KI überwachte Venturis die sechs Menschen, die bis vor kurzem noch auf der Station arbeiteten. Obwohl von diesen jede Spur fehlt, sind sie doch fast allgegenwärtig – zumindest virtuell. Denn an Bord von Tacoma existieren mehrere VR-Aufzeichnungen, die die Crewmitglieder als Hologramme in die Räume projizieren und uns so die Möglichkeit geben, herauszufinden, was sich an Bord abspielte. Die etwa zwei Stunden lange Geschichte hat dabei einen sehr dystopischen Einschlag, was es schlussendlich mit Venturis und seiner KI auf sich hat, wird hier natürlich nicht verraten, es sei aber so viel gesagt, dass die Story interessant und logisch erzählt wird und mit einigen Wendungen aufwarten kann.

The Crew 
Une capture d'écran de Tacoma
Par : CaptainTrailer


Tacoma ist ein klassischer Walking Simulator, in dem wir die verschiedenen Ebenen und Räume der Raumstation durchschreiten und an vorgegebenen Stellen die erwähnten Aufzeichnungen aktivieren, welche sich pausieren, vor- und zurückspulen lassen. Das ist auch notwendig, denn oft wurden alle sechs Mitglieder, Andrew, Roberta, Clieve, EV, Natali und Sareh, gleichzeitig aufgenommen, sodass die jeweiligen Konversationen parallel ablaufen, man aber jeweils nur einer zuhören kann – will man alles erleben, muss man also zurückspulen und so den Gesprächen an einer anderen Stelle lauschen. Um mehr über die Geschichte und das Leben der Besatzung zu erfahren können zudem Chatverläufe, Briefe, Zeitungsartikel und Mails gefunden und eingesehen werden – das ist natürlich etwas Lesearbeit, die man prinzipiell auch ignorieren kann, aber nicht sollte, denn den Charakteren und der Geschichte wird so eine Menge Leben eingehaucht. Abgesehen davon, lassen sich auch viele Schubladen und Schränke durchsuchen oder Gegenstände aufnehmen, wirklich lohnen tut sich das aber leider nicht – hier wäre sicherlich etwas mehr drin gewesen. Dadurch, dass es nur wenige, sehr einfache Rätsel gibt, keinerlei Zeitdruck herrscht und man auch nicht sterben kann, ist Tacoma alles in allem eine entspannte Angelegenheit, die man auch problemlos in einem Rutsch durchspielen kann.

synchronizing 
Une capture d'écran de Tacoma
Par : CaptainTrailer


Grafisch ist Tacoma sehr ansehnlich geraten, das klare Highlight sind hier die dargestellten Hologramm-Figuren, die sich bunt, liebevoll animiert und lebensecht präsentieren. Aber auch die Umgebung ist hübsch geraten, die Licht- und Schatteneffekte überzeugen und die in den Raum projizierten Chatlogs und Mails passen zur Thematik. Alle Dialoge wurden professionell, aber nur auf Englisch, vertont, für sie gibt es aber eine einwandfreie deutsche Übersetzung, auch die Umgebungstexte per Overlay übersetzt. Besondere Erwähnung verdient hier noch der Soundtrack, der mir wirklich unheimlich gut gefallen hat und von dem ich mir wirklich wünschen würde, dass man ihn separat erwerben könnte. Technisch lief Tacoma weitestgehend rund und auf höchsten Einstellungen mit 60 FPS, lediglich in den Reise-Sequenzen zwischen den Ebenen hatte ich immer wieder unerklärliche Framedrops. An einer anderen Stelle fror das Spiel komplett ein, sodass sich nicht mal der Task-Manager öffnen ließ, nach wenigen Minuten lief das Spiel dann von alleine weiter – von daher ist das erwähnenswert, aber nicht weiter tragisch.

Fazit

Tacoma ist ein kurzer Walking Simulator, der eine interessante Geschichte über Tech-Unternehmen, den Umgang mit KI und im erweiterten Sinne auch über das zivilisierte Zusammenleben an sich erzählt. Dazu sieht das Spiel hübsch aus und liefert einen tollen Soundtrack, lediglich der fehlende, spielerische Anspruch dürfte nicht jedem gefallen. Man sollte diese Art von Spiel also mögen, etwas Lesebereitschaft mitbringen und aufgrund der Kürze und des geringen Wiederspielwertes würde ich auch eher zu einem Kauf im Sale raten, dann ist Tacoma aber eine lohnenswerte Investition.

Mehr Reviews gibt es auf meiner Kuratorenseite. :)
 
CaptainTrailer

Évaluation publiée le 8 janvier 2018
游戏吸引我的地方就是它的叙事方式，很新颖很生动，而且这种方式非常真实，一群人分开后，会在同一时间轴上发生不同的事情，不同的话题、内容，是现实生活很相似。故事不长，但五脏俱全。结局很有意思。但是撒花后还是需要有人科普一下背景故事。整体来说，是一块很有创意很有特点的步行模拟器。

Recommandé
3.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 octobre 2018
Acabo de jugar este juego, en una experiencia compartida ♥♥♥ alguien que en general no le da una importancia a la historia en los videojuegos y mucho menos piensa que son un arte, bueno, pensaba ya que este juego lo convenció de que la narrativa en un videojuego es algo que se puede explotar a su forma y no debe ser reemplazada por ninguno de los otros medios.

El juego nos pone en la piel de nuestra protagonista tratando de descubrir que pasó en una nave llamada "Tacoma", para hacerlo veremos cosas que han pasado en la nave ♥♥♥ detalles en todas las habitaciones que nos ayudan a empatizar ♥♥♥ los personajes de forma natural y satisfactoria, si bien me gustaria decirles un poco más sobre la historia, creo que deberían experimentarlo por ustedes mismos ya que es algo magico y cualquier cosa que diga puede ser un gran spoiler.

Los movimientos en el juego son fluidos y muy responsivos excepto cuando estas en la gravedad cero que hace que tu personaje se mueva todo el tiempo y por ello no puedes tener una vista cinematografica del momento.

Las mecanicas aplicadas en este juego son las tipicas de un walking simulator excepto que aquí, para descubrir que pasó, debemos retroceder en el tiempo viendo y escuchando, a través de hologramas, lo que pasó ♥♥♥ la tripulación de Tacoma

La optimización en general esta muy bien y es una experiencia fluida a más de 60fps en la mayor parte de la experiencia pero en ciertas partes el juego recibe unos cuantos bajones de frames que te sacan bastante de la experiencia.

Por todo esto y más le doy al juego un merecido: 8.7/10

La historia no deja que desear viniendo de los creadores de Gone Home ♥♥♥ partes emocionantes y algunas que nos dejan ♥♥♥ dudas para que podamos hacer nuestras propias teorias mientras y luego de haberlo jugado, el juego es muy detallado y todas las zonas tienes pequeñas cosas escondidas que nos ayudan a conectar más ♥♥♥ el juego.
 
Roxas

评论区有剧情简介，非常建议看一下简介再买。我知道这是一个剧情游戏，但正因为剧情对于游戏体验很重要，所以这种幼稚的剧情实在不推荐。实际上，我不觉得剧透不剧透有什么差别，白开水一样的剧情。然后就是，如果不是步行模拟器爱好者，强烈不推荐。

Évaluation publiée le 21 juin 2022
I have no problem with walking sims at all, as long as they have a good story. And that is not the case here. The story is just OK, a pretty simple plot once you assemble the few pieces, with a "I saw it coming" plot twist at the end. But don't expect a complex story with well developed characters, just a simple plot revealed in small pills easy to assemble. Maybe if the game was longer, it could have developed the characters more, but...

Non recommandé
1.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 novembre 2018
Sadly, there are rather few games in old good science fiction settings, so I had high hopes for Tacoma, especially considering previous experience with Gone Home.

But Tacoma proved to be very uninvolving.

Characters whose story player is supposed to discover can hardly be called relatable, their personalities raise a lot of questions. How did such vulnerable and unqualified people end up in an isolated environment for prolonged period of time? Nobody cared to perform even the most superficial interview before assembling a space station crew? Instead of following emergency protocols which definitely should be present in such a place characters indulge themselves with lengthy "self-exploring" talks.

But the worst thing is actually the absence of any game per se. In Gone Home you had to actively compare what you've read and seen and actively search for clues. Here you just walk from one terminal to another watching AR silhouettes. The most fun there is playing basketball in zero gravity inside rotating main corridor, which doesn't have anything to do with "deep story" of Tacoma.

Wiki says this concept of just following characters wherever you want was inspired by a live play. Well, it's a great idea for a play, but awful for a video game.
 
RiD
1
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 décembre 2020
My best way to describe this way is a nice story. It's a walking simulator with very little puzzles and the only thing the player has to do most of the time is press buttons to reveal more of the story. If that's not your thing, this game is not for you. That being said, by the middle of the story I was pretty invested and was genuinely interested in the characters and cared for them. Even the AI. I personally would have liked a little more gameplay in some way and found myself trudging through the first hour of the game before I got really hooked, but at that point it was very enjoyable. It's a story that unravels little by little and overall I'd say it's worth a playthrough if you're into this kind of thing.
 
Don_rosa

Évaluation publiée le 28 mars 2020
Excellent. TACOMA est un jeu simulateur de randonnée où vous incarnez une employée chargée de récupérer des données sur une station orbitale. Vous allez devoir rejouer en réalité augmentée les événements étant survenus dans cette station pour comprendre l'histoire de ce qui s'est déroulé. C'est vraiment un très bon jeu, avec de bonnes musiques, une bonne ambiance et surtout, de beaux décors de vide spatial.

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
3.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 janvier 2019
Прекрасный симулятор ходьбы на один вечер, основанный на живом театре, где события происходят одновременно в разных местах, поэтому вам приходится отматывать записи и погружаться в происходящее всё глубже и глубже.

Общая фабула истории неплохая, только порой уж слишком ощущается давление авторов в сторону нетрадиционной сексуальной ориентации (две пары ЛГБТ на одну традиционную, половина женского экипажа - дамы в теле; ни одного белого мужика кроме главного подонка), что крупные компании сволочи, а также что нужно всех защищать от этих плохих компаний. Словно авторы обижены на кого-то конкретного. Ну или просто создавали историю в угоду веяниям времени. Впрочем, это тот редкий случай, когда всё это не испортило сюжет, вовсе нет. Диалоги прописаны добротно, окружение станции создано с любовью.

Погружаться в происходящее очень интересно. Со скидкой - надо брать.
 
vernonroshe

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 février 2021
Play this in one sitting. Seriously. It won't take you 4 hours to see everything the story has to offer, and boy is that a lot. You will NOT get as good an experience if you stop in the middle and come back after sleeping, or doing something else.
Tacoma is a beautiful, rather wholesome story. Its gameplay is simple but unobtrusively so. It does not overstay its welcome, and offers a glimpse into a sci-fi universe which is understandable, familiar, and yet remarkably... whatever the opposite of fatalistic is. If you get it at a price at which 4 hours of gameplay (potentially 6 if you want to platinum it, which you may) does not sting you, I cannnot recommend this title enough.
 
Opp DeathAngel

3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 novembre 2017
Produit reçu gratuitement

Игра понравилась, как может понравится хорошая история в достойном исполнении. Ощущается как своего рода интерактивный фильм, в котором сопереживание к героям зашкаливает, потому что вот ты тут и видишь их "цифровые" следы, и понимаешь, что все не так просто, как кажется на первый взгляд.
Игра затрагивает глубокий вопрос о человечности и ответственности в декорациях технологического прогресса, что, несомненно, идет ей только в плюс! (Эй, камон, какой истории не к лицу философский подтекст?!)
9\10, за то что переодически лагало и вылетало. Но это же мелочи. Игра своих денег заслуживает. Круче, чем билет в кино.

Non recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 septembre 2017
I liked the AR concept, the characters, the voice acting, the art style. I was therefore really disappointed when I kept playing and discovered how incredibly boring it is.
The story was okay - not great, but okay. The biggest problem, I think, is the pacing; It's just so slow that I got bored, yet there were parts towards the end where I was starting to get into it, and then it sort of just ended...
Any parts of the game that may have been interesting were on rails and that just kills the immersion and made it boring again.
I loved the world they built, the stage was all set for something awesome; and then it fizzled out.

Recommandé
2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 aout 2017
Produit remboursé

Tacoma es un juego para los amantes del espacio, de la ciencia ficción y de las relaciones personales. Sabe enmarcarte en un entorno inmersivo a través de efectos de sonido y música no solo apabullantemente espacial sino realista ♥♥♥ el ambiente. Podría haber ahondado más en las relaciones entre personajes, crear romances para unir a cuatro tripulantes da la sensación de pereza. La duración no ha jugado buena pasada puesto que las mecánicas e historias son innovadoras y creativas. Una obra que podía haber llegado a más. 8,5/10.
 
chicabits
0
8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
13.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 aout 2017
Tacoma is the long waited successor to the game Gone Home. From the people who brought Gone Home comes Tacoma which is on par with Gone Home except set in space and in the future. So if you have played Gone Home, then you will feel right at home with this one. Even if you haven't played Gone Home, this game doesn't require playing Gone Home to know what is going on. Though I do recommend checking out Gone Home if you don't know the hype for it. Now for the plot of Tacoma, the game is set in the year 2088 A.D. approximately 93 years after the year Gone Home took place in. You assume the role as a woman named Amy Ferrier, an employee of a space station operations company called Venturis, who is assigned to a mission by traveling to the abandon space station Tacoma, and learn what was the fate of the crew that operated the station. The movement and audio records of the crew are all monitored with the use of an augmented reality program where you "visually" see the crew members' actions and movements with the audio records that are found in certain sections of the space station. As you progress in each section of the station, you slowly learn more about the crew by finding their living quarters, documents, photos, text messages, and objects that help establish who each of the crew members are. This game was a great addition to Gone Home as it has a similar game structure except with better visuals and a more complex plot. There is more voice acting than what was offered in Gone Home, Sarah Grayson who voiced Sam from Gone Home returns as the voice of Amy for this game. While Gone Home was a period game, this one is a not too distant future setting. It's unknown what the world will be like in the year 2088, but I do like how the game explored subject matters that either improved or worsen by the year 2088. Show casing that as human beings evolve, society will always have its share of problems. If you like narative exploration games like Gone Home, then this game is a must for anyone who likes to sit back and explore a wonderious future that may yet to come.
 
emasterslake
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 février 2018
Después de Gone Home, Fullbright nos trae Tacoma, un juego que sigue totalmente ♥♥♥ el estilo de juego de su antecesor. La premisa inicial es que debemos completar una misión de reconocimiento dentro de la estación espacial Tacoma, recuperando datos de texto y audio, similar a Gone Home. Solo que esta vez, los desarrolladores van un poco más allá y ahora también podemos escuchar y ver conversaciones que tuvieron los tripulantes dentro de la estación, debido a que un sistema grababa sus movimientos y sonidos, y ahora nosotros podemos "vivir" esas grabaciones gracias a un aparato de realidad virtual que llevamos puesto. A partir de ahi, debemos reconstruir y descubrir que ocurrió en aquel lugar.

La historia es muy buena, y a parte de ser un buen relato de supense y cienca ficción, toca temas sociales y politicos, amorosos, tecnológicos etc. A lo largo de toda la experiencia, se profundiza mucho en las relaciones personales entro todos los habitantes de la estación, y también las relaciones ♥♥♥ los seres queridos que no ven desde hace mucho tiempo. Además, como he comentado antes, la estructura narrativa es bastante atipica, y a pesar de que los registros principales de realidad virtual (que en la mayoria de casos los encontramos en orden cronológico), una parte muy importante de la historia reside en los objetos en el escenario. La historia es bastante redonda, y concluye bastante bien toda la aventura.

Jugablemente, es muy simple, andar a través de las instalaciones, y coger los objetos que nos encontremos simplemente para verlos en detalle. También, de vez en cuando debemos buscar contraseñas para atravesar algunas puertas bloqueadas, aunque es muy sencillo. Y por supuesto, navegar a través de las grabaciones para encontrar detalles y escuchar todas las conversaciones.

Audiovisualmente tiene muy buen nivel: gran detalle en la mayoría de modelados, buenas texturas, y una gran iluminacion a tiempo real que le da un aspecto magnífico. El diseño artistico también es genial, y el sonido y doblaje son muy buenos. En cuanto al rendimiento, en algunos momentos donde la carga gráfica es mayor, me bajaba de los 60 fps, pero la mayor parte de la aventura está muy bien optimizada.

Recomiendo este juego, sin duda para los jugadores que buscan buenas historias y un genial apartado audiovisual, aunque si quieres algo de complejidad o variedad en cuanto a las mecánicas jugables, quizás te decepcione. De todas maneras, por el precio irrisorio de +-1 euro, es imprescindible darle al menos una oportunidad aunque no te llame demasiado la atención.
 
Oscarcillo100
1

While the game has a fantastic story which I really enjoyed, and a really unique, cool way of reliving the events the befell the Tacoma, it is SHORT! Going through every little bit of content the game has to offer shouldn't take you more than 2-3 hours and it has little to no replayability. That said, it was a great ride and I really enjoyed it - I just don't think I'd spend more than $5 on it .

Évaluation publiée le 3 aout 2017
This game is basically an interactive movie, with the nice additional touch that you have to rewind certain scenes because multiple conversations or activities are taking place in different areas. It has one or two "find the key" or "find the code for this touchpad" moments, but other than that, this is a linear story.

The question then becomes whether you want to pay $20 for a three-hour somewhat-interactive movie.

I thought it was a pretty good movie, and with movie prices what they are where I live, I've paid that much to see things I liked less.
 
columbine
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 octobre 2019
Games like Tacoma sure got a bad reputation when they first came out. But since they’ve become more accepted into the mainstream the quality has gone up considerably! Tacoma is an experience to be had and if you enjoyed What Remains of Edith Finch then you’ll enjoy Tacoma too.

To start, the game looks good. The atmosphere of the space station is perfect. It feels completely plausible for the future. I can only imagine how much time they put into placing all these little objects around. Items like food and books all the way down to different toothbrushes in each of the crew’s bathrooms.

All those details have a purpose. To give you a sense of who these people were and what the hell happened in this space station. You see, it’s completely empty. You only experience what happened through augmented reality. Upon entering an area where playback is available you can start it up and not only listen to the crew’s conversation but also see their movements. I enjoyed seeing the characters act naturally. One might be chatting to the station’s AI while playing pool and others might be recording a report. You can follow each before they come together for a group conversation. It feels so normal. It’s much better than an audio log, we’ve come a long way since Dear Esther.

It’s Tacoma’s greatest accomplishment. I can easily describe the different crew members and their personalities. That this is so much more than listening to people chat.

That said, it IS a walking simulator. If you don’t want to experience a story well then Tacoma isn’t going to change your mind. I would recommend What Became of Edith Finch over Tacoma too. That was more unique and had interesting mechanics. Tacoma is a little on the bland side and the story is unique but not mind blowing. It definitely hits on a few topics that could potentially be coming up for humans in the future. It doesn’t try and fork the topic in your eye which I appreciate. Feeds into the natural feeling of the game.

Overall, Tacoma is good and I liked it. The voyeur way you can watch the crew makes it unique. It doesn’t drag on either and the rewind system means it doesn’t waste your time re-watching the crew. If you like these types of games you’ll like Tacoma too.

Click to see my curator for more reviews!
 
peppage
1,621 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 juillet 2018
Tacoma is a lovely little game from the people who made Gone Home - another beautiful gem of a game experience. This time we're in space far in the future on board an abandoned orbital station. We're dropped into the game without much in the way of context, but that's for us to discover through Fullbright's familiar storytelling style.

The voice acting is wonderful and the pacing and story-telling through recorded moments and AR "diary-type" entries is excellent! And like Gone Home, it tells its story coherently through these snippets of human moments. You glean personality and backstory that's pertinent to the experience and gives you enough to form an emotional connection. It's also continuing a happy trend of normalizing lgbtq representation in video game stories (without the "bury your gays" tropes) - much in the way Gone Home was.

I'm glad Fullbright is building on it's style of subtle narrative and "found-story" methods of delivering a gameplay experience that's both intelligent and emotionally evocative. And it's full of little details and touches that made me smile and flesh out the game world (I loved the use of sign language to interact with the AR systems - it makes sense!)

My first playthrough was just over 2.5 hours which might feel like it's a little short for the full price, but it's absolutely 2 hours worth playing.

Definitly pick this up!

Recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 aout 2017
I loved Gone Home, it really changed the way I thought about video games. I didn't realize how personal and emotionally gripping a game could be. Tacoma is the follow up from that same team. What I learned from this is that they turned everything up much higher but with the same mindset as in Gone Home.

What I mean by that largely resides on time, it took me a little over 2 hours to complete. The characters in this game are incredible. They have a lot of personality and are very deep, there is a lot of backstory to explore here and I explored every piece you could in the game. My issue was that they didn't explore that enough. With Gone Home, the focus was on two people and in 2 hours they were able to develop those characters well. In this game, we have 6 or so characters in this game but it wasn't much longer in terms of time of play. I left this game wanting more, lots more. I wanted to know more about their history and their moments here.

This was a great game, no doubt about it, but I think they had way more room to expand upon this world and give me more information and allow more time for the story to develop. It's funny, most of the time I think a game should be shorter, this is one where it could have benefited from being longer.

Also, please make this in VR, this is perfect for virtual reality.
 
VertigoSFX
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 avril 2018
I wasn't a great fan of Gone Home, Fullbright's previous game, but really enjoyed this. Taking place in an abandoned space station, Tacoma tasks you with exploring the station, learning about the events leading up to the station's evacuation by interacting with 'augmented reality' recordings of the crew during certain key events. The level of detail that's been put into designing the world is extremely impressive, making Tacoma station highly compelling to explore. The story that unfolds is similarly engaging, heightened by the unusual means of telling it, with the AR recordings being a similar style to 'immersive theatre'. Highly recommended.
 
Illusionary

ic1
1,044 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
15.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 avril 2020
2º juego de Fullbright. Llegas a una estación espacial donde has de averiguar qué ha sido de la tripulación. ¿Están vivos o están muertos?

PROS

Si te gustó Gone Home, este juego también te gustará. Hay mucho que leer en lo que te enterarás de sentimientos, secretos, etc de la tripulación, así como de la compañía propietaria.

La física del juego es impresionante. Puedes coger y girar objetos para verlos de todos los lados. También puedes lanzarlos o llevarlos en la mano por todos sitios.
El broche de oro es la zona de gravedad 0 que te hace sentir como si lo estuvieras de verdad.

La música acompaña bien y los gráficos son muy realistas para estar en una estación espacial.

Algunos critican que se juega en 2h. No les hagais caso.
Yo he disfrutado 13h examinándolo todo, leyéndolo, escuchar todas las conversaciones desde todos los ángulos (personas) y cómo no, haciendo los logros.

CONTRAS

Tiene algún bug ocasional (es muy raro ver uno, pero alguno vi) pero que se arregla saliendo del juego a Steam y volverlo a arrancar.
A pesar de ello, sigo recomendado comprarlo cuando lo veas algo rebajado.

CONSEJOS

Si quieres disfrutarlo a tope hazte esta pregunta: ¿habrá una pista detrás de un objeto si le doy la vuelta? Y te pondrás a manipularlos todos (libros, posavasos, bolis, lápices, y todo lo que imagines).

Yo fui haciendo copias del directorio de save, siempre por si acaso. Pero me fue útil para quedarme ♥♥♥ el save en cierto momento emocionante antes del final del juego (un momento entrañable y esclarecedor antes de llegar a la escena final del juego).

La ruta del directorio de saves:

Windows: %USERPROFILE%\AppData\LocalLow\Fullbright\Tacoma\
Linux: $HOME/.config/unity3d/Fullbright/Tacoma/

Non recommandé
5.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 mars 2018
J'ai pris bien mon temps pour tout lire et tout écouter : 3h et Je suis plutôt déçu.

Les thèmes sont très intéressants et donc le scénario également, sauf que le manque de substance m'a frustré.
Il ya beaucoup d'attention sur des détails qui, s'ils ajoutent au réalisme, n'apportent pas grand chose en fin de compte.

A mon avis, ce jeu est trop court. Trop court dans le sens où il y a matière à l'étoffer beaucoup plus niveau scénario et relations interpersonnelles et situations diverses. Je déplore le fait que le background du jeu ne soit pas plus étayé et expliqué et que la séquence de fin paraisse aussi abrupte.

Il ne vaut pas 20 euros celon moi et j'ai encore trouvé que 10 c'était un peu cher.

PS : Les succès ne posent aucun problème et sont assez amusants à faire.

Recommandé
3.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 juin 2019
Oui, mais...

D'un point de vue technique c'est super bien fait! Vraiment l'AR est super bien pensé, l'ambiance est très bien rendue, nickel.

Mais... mais ce jeu aurait mérité un meilleur scénario. Pas histoire, hein. L'histoire est TRES bien. Mais une meilleure façon de raconter cette histoire. C'est trop timide dans l'intention. Je n'ai pas tellement eu l'impression de jouer, mais de contempler. Et c'est frustrant parce que j'ai été très bien immergé dans le concept MAIS j'ai été très limité dans la réalisation.

Je le recommande pour les joueurs occasionnels qui veulent se promener et les collectionneurs de succès. Pour ceux qui veulent enquêter vous allez être frustrés. Si vous voulez juste une bonne histoire de SF, c'est pas mal du tout. Peut-être un peu cher.
 
Carcax

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 février 2018
Un piccolo diamante, ma essendo diamante è pur sempre prezioso no?

♥♥♥ questa piccola premessa inizio a descrivere un piccolo capolavoro che ho scoperto per caso (preso ♥♥♥ il bundle di febbraio di Humble Bundle). Di solito non sono un'amante di questo genere di giochi, amo l'azione sì ma ♥♥♥ sempre una storia interessante in mezzo, ma Tacoma è una bellissima eccezione. Dividero la recensione nelle varie sezioni e nel finale un piccolo commento.

Storia: Senza vari spoiler importanti (si basa il gioco solo su questo) siamo Amy una collaboratrice di una famosa azienda spaziale deve andare nella stazione Tacoma ad indagare cosa sia successo usando un dispositivoi che permette di rivivere le esperienze registrate nella stazione (private e no) qui mi fermo ma vi posso garantire che proseguendo vi innamorerete.

Grafica: Non avrà una grafica eccellente ma è pulitissima, ogni dettaglio è perfetto unica pecca è un pò di cali mentre scendi o sali da un piano all'altro della stazione!

Sonoro:Semplice e piacevole ♥♥♥ canzoni rilassanti e sopratutto ottime cantanti (capirete!)

Gameplay:Beh è quasi innesistente (tranne per alcuni mini giochi sparsi nella stazione)


Conclusione: è una delle migliori esperienze del genere che abbia provato, peccato (parere mio) il costo un pò eccessivo ma che comunque ripaga a chi ama il genere!
8.5/10
 
Francyz

Évaluation publiée le 4 octobre 2017
Did you like Gone Home? If Yes, then buy Tacoma.

If no, then don't.

If you didn't play Gone Home, do so, then come back.

To clarify, it's a game about exploring a space and putting together events after the fact. There isn't any danger or urgency, and it's very much a part of the "walking simulator" genre. If you, like me, enjoy that style of game then it's a good entry and well worth looking at.

8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 aout 2017
I adore the walking simulator genre, and this was one of the best walking games I've played. The characters feel very real and lived in, as does the ship. Like Gone Home, there are plenty of small personal details to discover if you're willing to snoop (and if you're playing this sort of game, I assume you're more than willing). All of the objects - from photos to notes to coins to books - have been placed extremely deliberately to add to story and character.

The main mechanic of the game is playing through partially corrupted augmented reality holograms of the crew, and uncovering their emails/notes/texts. You can follow one conversation, rewind, and go follow a different conversation - like a slightly more controllable version of "Sleep No More". There isn't much in the way of puzzles - a few passcodes that you can enter in the right place to unlock specific areas, a few physical keys hidden in drawers, that sort of thing.

The game also includes excellent representation - POC, women in tech, queer couples, and combinations thereof, while crafting them all into unique and full characters (except possibly the player character, who is left mostly unexplored).

It is short - I played just over 4 hours and I'm very much a "stop-and-look-and-contemplate-everything" kind of player, but I've played longer games that had far less to them. I think if you enjoy this sort of game to start with, it's well worth your time and your money.
 
gryffindorable

Recommandé
5.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 mai 2019
From the creators of Gone Home, comes this Gone to Space Station game :)
Its an awkward situation where I am not sure to recommend or not this game. Basically its a walking sim adventure with elements of research and investigation, but at a very basic and narrow way.
There is interesting new way of presenting a story, through events depicted in 3D environment, happening around you. Where you can control, play, pause events and access additional information.
Its a shame those figures are only wireframe 3d models representing real characters in environment, explained through AR tech and not rendered as real chars in game.
Dont expect much control or some big investigation procedure, basically story is unfolded before you as you follow along.
Already seen story with an interesting ending with expected space / AI / disaster scenario in space.

Évaluation publiée le 5 février 2018
It's only about as long as a movie and doesn't have much in the way of interactivity, but the writing, acting, set design, and general style really elevate this into something worth checking out. Basically, it's a movie with you as the camera man, but the environmental story-telling is on par with classic Valve stuff, from back when they made campaigns instead of polishing up multiplayer mods. It's a real shame there isn't VR support, this game feels like it was designed ground up for it, and that market seems to be more willing to spend $20 bucks on a cool little experience that only lasts a few hours. Still, I recommend it...when it's on sale.

Évaluation publiée le 7 novembre 2021
TACOMA is an interactive story, 'walking simulator' type of game. There is not much "gameplay" per se but to the extent there is, it's good. UI, controls etc are all great.

The story is extremely interesting and well written. 10/10 story.

I looked in every nook and cranny I could, and completing the game took me 3 hours, so 3 hours of gameplay to get through it.

If this all sounds good to you, you like walking sims, would like an interactive movie/story experience, like scifi etc, I can easily recommend this. Very well done this game is.

Non recommandé
2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 février 2018
Got this as part of a Humble Bundle. Thankfully. I'd be really pissed off otherwise.

Tacoma is a walking simulator. It is not an "adventure", nor is it particularly "interactive". There are no "choices", there are no "multiple paths". All of that could be inferred from the store page, because it's written at least a bit ambiguously. Only at the very end of the store page do they basically admit it's a "non-game" that takes between 2-5 hours. I don't know where the remaining 3 hours were supposed to come from by the way. I watched every scene, read every piece of information...maybe from random objects? But to be honest, neither the game world nor the characters are interesting enough to really dig around even more.

Now, walking sims are all about the story, atmosphere, etc. And this is imho where Tacoma simply fails to deliver. The space station isn't particularly interesting, nor are the gay and non-gay couples that need to be shoehorned into everything nowadays. There's barely any conflict in the few recordings and most of the fluff information is either half scrambled or uninteresting. You barely scratch the surface of each character. Damnit, Wolfenstein had more interesting and deep characters and that was an FPS.

The story is also pretty meh in my opinion. There's not really anything compelling or twisting about it. Only at the end you might say "aha", but then the game is over aaaaand, well...the ending doesn't really affect the story or anything you've experienced up to this point, so who cares -.-

I just don't know how you can justify asking for 20 bucks for what is basically nothing? This is why I have to give it a thumbs down. Not because I hated the game, I just found it a bit lacking and boring, just interesting enough to complete, but man, not for 20 bucks...maybe for 5.
 
Dire
1,160 produits enregistrés
1
10 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 aout 2017
I've been waiting two years for this game, anticipation building, and it was so, so worth it.

Tacoma is clearly a Fullbright game, as thematically thoughtful and tightly written as Gone Home, if without some of the timely punch their first title had. Which is not to say that Tacoma is any less engaging or even groundbreaking in terms of its chosen cast -- actually, it's definitely more so. It only feels less exciting because Fullbright already laid down this path with Gone Home, so the shock factor of seeing characters who aren't simultaneously straight, white, or male is lessened. Instead, it feels expected in the best sort of way.

There's loads more to explore in Tacoma than Gone Home. Gone Home had the unfortunate weakness of being completely (and even accidentally) spoilable. Players preemptively exposed to the major twist or even barebones plot were left without much else to explore and discover, and largely unaffected by the atmospherics. Tacoma solves this problem by incorporating multiple intertwining story threads and letting the player explore them in depth at their own pace. Although there is a Fullbright Twist in the third act, it isn't the driving force or even most memorable portion of the story. What stays with you are the quieter moments, like the notes characters leave on the inside of their gym lockers.

The mechanics, too, are completely different. Where Gone Home was fundamentally similar to Escape The Room games -- click everything, open every box, read all the papers -- with a side of Bioshock-esque diary recordings supported by brilliant and thorough set design, Tacoma is something new. Almost like an interactive movie, Tacoma invites players to walk around and seek out the details in character-populated and fully voiced cut scenes. It is quite literally like walking through a town full of NPCs, going about their lives without noticing you. An exercise in voyeuristic viewership with a bit of clicking-around thrown in. If you unironically love activating story events and reading the optional in-game lore materials as much as I do, then Tacoma is the game for you.

Tacoma rewards a detail-oriented play style. Despite flagging most key plot developments as Important and intentionally making them easy to find, the majority of the world building and character exploration is contained in branching side rooms and small interactive objects that players in a hurry (like the disgruntled Polygon reviewer) might miss. Considering that the depth of futurism is actually key to understanding the ending and completely missable if the player refuses to deviate from the bare-bones storyline, playing Tacoma in a hurry is a huge mistake. All in all, searching through every corner of the game took me about five hours, which I consider time well spent.

The graphics and art design are, once again, beautiful, and even better than Gone Home. The game did immediately start me out on the lowest graphic setting -- don't be fooled, this isn't an indy game with glitchy pixelated corners. The high settings for the graphics are completely gorgeous.

Expect to fall in love with the cast (yes, even the AI) and cry at the end. 10/10.
 
gooseklein

Évaluation publiée le 23 novembre 2017
A game full of endearing characters living in a strangely relatable sci-fi world. While the visuals aren’t especially stunning the augmented reality system used by the game’s characters has a wonderful style. As in Gone Home, Fullbright demonstrate their considerable skill in subtle environmental storytelling, with the objects placed around the Tacoma space station telling small stories that are never stated out loud.

The uplifting narrative that sees the best in people when they are working together is very much appreciated.
 
Fuzzball
348 produits enregistrés

8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 octobre 2017
It’s a sci-fi 3D adventure in first person view set in the abandoned orbital station Tacoma, a commercial transfer point between Earth and Moon. You are Amy Ferrier, an agent of Venturis, the corporation who owns Tacoma. Story takes place in 2088. Your mission is to discover what happened to Tacoma’s crew and retrieve all data registered by on board AI. You are equipped with an augmented reality device that allows to review actions and conversations of the crew. The six not playable characters appears as human shapes with no faces, distinguished by colors and icons; you can see their faces only on the profiles of the communication system. The on board AI, Odin, is the seventh not palyable character.

Gameplay is centered around exploration of the orbital station, checking for documents and clues. I liked the simulation of inertia while moving in absence of gravity. Your main purpose is analyzing AR data, as you were watching filmed sequences. You can rewind, pause or forward action and have to intercept communication data of the crew. Not so much: too passive and static, not involving and sometime annoying task. Characters are represented as colored shapes, so is not so exciting to follow their actions; voice acting is more interesting, but dialogues are not so compelling: personalities of the characters are a bit down.

Rating and full review on my website: https://vgartsite.wordpress.com/2017/10/15/gone-home-tacoma/
 
Lucafg - Video Games & Art
3
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
1.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 mars 2018
В Tacoma показывается мир будущего, в котором работа на космических станциях стала заурядным делом, сравнимым с командировками в отдалённые районы страны. Главной героине предстоит даже более спокойная работа: ей надо выкачать и доставить заказчикам информацию, собранную искусственным интеллектом корабля. Несложная, но долгая и нудная работа.

Ждать и смотреть на то, как медленно перекачиваются файлы можно, но скучновато, хотя никто не мешает именно так и поступить. Но гораздо интереснее побродить по кораблю и изучить, как здесь жили люди. Получить больше информации о причине, по которой станция была покинута, а также о проблемах и радостях каждого члена экипажа.

Сразу на входе тебя встречает система дополненной реальности. Почти что игра в игре, хотя на станции она выполняет рабочую, а не развлекательную функцию. Она добавляет интерактивные подсказки, записывает действия и разговоры персонала и просто помогает в сложных ситуациях. Например, если не знаешь как сделать торт, всегда можно обратиться к ней за подробным руководством.

Такие игры, как Tacoma, похожи на виртуальные музеи. Ты просто ходишь, исследуя окружающий мир. Маленький застывший отрезок чьей-то истории, в котором, в отличии от обычных музеев, всё можно потрогать и рассмотреть вблизи. Поэтому тут и интересно.
 
kellion
650 produits enregistrés

10 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
3.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 aout 2017
Beautifully written and artfully constructed. From first entering Tacoma to finally leaving the station I was intrigued and immersed. The characters are engaging, each with their own tidbits of backstory, and the dialogue and story never felt forced or overdone like some other narrative games.

If a good plot and an air of intrigue are what you look for in a game, then Tacoma will fill that need very well.

Things that I wish had been improved or expanded on are the "puzzle" aspects of the game and the graphics for the holograms. The codes for some of the doors were hidden in clever ways, but these are few and far between. I wish there had been more locked areas with increasingly challenging codes for me to discover. Also, I know this is probably a petty gripe all in all, but during each AR playback I was increasingly distracted by the holograms lined-through bodies and hands. And I know if I was noticing it a lot someone else is too.

But despite these qualms I very much reccomend Tacoma, and will be replaying it many times over.
 
ADubs

Évaluation publiée le 5 aout 2017
I love Tacoma, well done Fullbright team! I thoroughly enjoyed my experience in Gone Home - getting connected to its characters and uncovering their stories.

With this game, the characters are very easy to invest in emotionally as you discover all their individual traits. SO many little touches which help world build and make the crews living quarters believable, like the pile of decorations in the makeshift storage room.

I don't recognise this critque of the game being too short. The game is as long as it takes you to soak everything in. its clear a great amount of thought effort and time went into it all and I wish more people would see that so they could enjoy it.

Cost is weird subject. Its down to the player what they believe their money is worth. To me, this was worth the cost.

Slashko
339 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 mars 2018
A contractor, the player is sent to Tacoma space-station to investigate what happened to it's crew, and to retrieve recordings the boarding AI has made. This is achieved through a first person perspective.

As you roam through the spacestation, in a practically linear way, you encounter video recordings of the crew and their occupancies and conversations. These videos can be rewinded, forwarded and replayed as much as you want. A necessity, because not all of the actions and conversations take place in the same room, but they do at the same time. A very nice mechanic, it let's the player be it's own director, since you can replay the happenings from different viewpoints. You can even walk around while the recordings are playing.

Tacoma is a walking simulator in the sence, that the player has little input, to disrupt or alter the storyline. Besides from watching the video recordings, there is nothing else that is required to make the game progress. A vast majority of the fun however, comes from the extras that can be explored and found. Sniffing around in the personnel quarters, digging through their personal stuff, and in this way getting to know a bit more of the NPC's, is key here.

Nearly all items can be picked up and rotated, to be inspected in detail. Design of the, mostly futuristic, objects is very well done. Many of these items are provided by Venturis, the future corporate tycoon, who also owns the Tacoma space-station. It's these references and little details that show that there's put a lot of thought into the package, besides the main storyline. Looked at from a socially critical, maybe even dystopian point of view. However, there could have, should have, been a bit more mystery in the plot, in the line of Firewatch for example.

Extremely enjoyable: the fact that the graphics in the game feet utterly smooth, refreshing and spotless, just like one would have imagined the space-station and it's inhabitants in the future to be alike. The colorful and vibrant stickman, blend seamlessly in with the beautiful, more pastelcolored, design of the space-station. All in great contrast with the cold, black void of space.

Voice acting is of superb quality, with each of the NPC's having it's own distinct voice, creating the real human behind the stickman. Music and sound effect all sound very clear and non-distorted, adding to the overall feel of the game in total.

Game was programmed in Unity 3D, a splendid job they did, i must add.

Please note however, because of the plot, it has almost no replayability. Aside from extra playthroughs, to complete all achievements perhaps. Somewhat a third of the achievements are unlocked, simply by completing the game. The rest of them are rather challenging and rewarding to discover by oneself. Since a playthrough is short, between 3-5 hours, a great pickup for achievement hunters as well.

To conclude, my time with Tacoma was a pleasant, refreshing experience that (re)kindled my love for walking simulators. Especially liked the peace-of-mind pace. The game let me choose when the story was told. Never feeling alone with the paused images of the stickman being around. This was another of those feel good games that made me feel privileged to have played it. I might be checking out "Going Home" as well, another game, their first official one, from indie developer Fullbright.

Definitely recommended for walking simulator fans, also beginners, and/or storyrich gamers who like a bit of a psychological twist.

Cheers,
SultanK
 
SultanK
4,606 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Évaluation publiée le 22 avril 2018
Среди призраков жизни.

Приготовьтесь к тому, что вам придется много слушать и читать. В этом всё удовольствие игры.
Если в "Gone Home" (игра от этих же разрабов) скитание по дому превращается в рутину, то Такома наоборот увлекает все больше и больше. Если вы втянетесь, вам определенно захочется узнать концовку игры.
За что точно хочется похвалить эту игру, так это за такой "натуральный мир". Все персонажи, чьи истории мы услышим, выглядят как живые и настоящие. А озвучка только прибавляет им "живости". Озвучку я вообще вынесу в отдельный плюс, настолько хорошо она получилась.
К тому же очень радует, что наконец-то есть просто хорошая и добрая инди игра, с глубоким сюжетом, но без [спойлер?] слезовыжималки.
 
Zaira_V

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 avril 2020
A simple black box recovery mission to a space station unearths a few mysteries in this story-driven short game. Nice diversion for a couple hours, you can listen to a lot of dialogue and read a ton of detail about the crewmember's lives. Also, there is a cat.

Two gripes, 1) some of the objects in the game and/or walls have collision detection problems, as an essential item for an achievement clipped straight through the walls of the space station and drifted off into space, never to be seen again. Had to replay entire game to get it, ultimately. 2) load times in the elevator shafts were a bit long, even on an SSD, and fps tanked every time in the elevators and a couple other times loading major scenes or recalling crew memories. Both bugs should have been patched by now, but it didn't ruin the game.

Solid 7/10 - not essential to play but still fun nevertheless; plus would probably be quite good in VR.

Évaluation publiée le 6 janvier 2018
As I do with most games, I bought this on a sale and am very glad that I did. As a walking simulator, it only took 3 hours to complete the game and get every achievement. There were little puzzles here and there and need from the gamer to have attention to detail in some cases. Overall, it was a relaxing game to play but not very satisfying at 3 hours of game play. I'd add I was excited about this game but under the impression it was going to be somewhat investigative in the events of what had happened on Tacoma. The game revealed everything to such a blunt point that the personal quarters of crew members felt like they were placed as a way to connect with the crew more. I wish I could return this game because I don't feel that, even discounted 50%, that it was worth it.

Non recommandé
5.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 aout 2017
Tacoma - Review

Tacoma es la nueva propuesta narrativa de los creadores de Gone Home, por lo tanto sigue las líneas generales de este último y no aporta absolutamente nada nuevo u original al género. En cuanto al título, Tacoma nos pone bajo el control de un espectador que debe descubrir los extraños sucesos que llevaron a la repentina desaparición de una tripulación espacial.
A base de registros de audio y una serie de documentos conectaremos los puntos de su atractiva trama y al mismo tiempo nos relacionaremos virtualmente ♥♥♥ cada uno de sus ausentes personajes. En cuanto a la historia, es atractiva y en ciertos momentos desarrolla algunos giros bruscos que pueden llegar a mantener el interés, pero posee ligera irregularidades como la ausencia de expresividad o las limitaciones interactivas al narrar sus hechos, simplemente no termina de funcionar bien su mecanica principal.

Al seguir el ritmo de Gone Home encontramos un título que abusa de la cantidad de objetos ♥♥♥ los que interactuar. Una enorme variedad de elementos para recoger y observar, de los cuales unos pocos afinaran lazos ♥♥♥ la trama principal. El resto funciona a modo decorativo y solo para mantener al jugador haciendo algo que lleva a la nada misma.
En cuanto a las mecánicas jugables, Tacoma es una aventura narrativa, por lo tanto la lectura es una de sus funciones principales, para ello deberemos analizar documentos, hackear terminales de Realidad Virtual o seguir los pasos de la tripulación en los días previos a su desaparición.
Por otro lado, Tacoma es un juego que se cocina a fuego lento, el ritmo de fuego es pausado y se toma su tiempo para introducir y construir a sus personajes. Además elabora una mecánica de juego intuitiva y simples. La única acción realmente importante que desarrollaremos en todo el juego es controlar las imágenes holográficas de la tripulación.
En un esquema de control preciso podremos avanzar o retroceder en los eventos y ♥♥♥ esto escucharemos conversaciones privadas o seremos testigos de las actividades que desempeñan ♥♥♥ el resto de sus compañeros. En cierta forma es una idea genial, pero deja un sabor agridulce. No termina de explotar todo su potencial y eventualmente se torna en algo repetitivo, ya que para conocer todos los detalles de la trama deberemos vivir el mismo evento una y otra vez, pero desde la visión del resto de personajes.

Uno de sus pocos atributos es la elaboracion de sus personajes, quienes se asemejan mas a una persona real e intentan romper ♥♥♥ la media. Por lo tanto, encontramos sujetos más humanos ♥♥♥ una reflexión especial sobre la vida.
Es un claro reflejo de la propia naturaleza de los seres humanos. Además, el arco argumental de cada uno de ellos, como también sus diálogos están muy bien conseguidas y captan interés, ya que son el mecanismo principal para atraparnos en su elegante escenario de soledad. Pero, esto se cae lentamente a pedazos al extendernos por su aventura.
Al tener tan solo un puñado de minutos para oír sus charlas o analizar sus actividades, la conexión tiende a disolverse rápidamente y ese nexo que buscan fundir ♥♥♥ el espectador desaparece en un segundo.

Por otro lado, algo que me resulto curioso es el diseño del personaje principal, por momentos es visible y en otro invisible. Otro detalle que capto mi atención es la nula expresividad ♥♥♥ unas líneas de diálogos escasas y animaciones fluctuantes.
Los rasgos físicos suelen desaparecer y aparecer cuando lo creen necesario, y al echar la mirada al suelo o interactuar ♥♥♥ determinados elementos notaremos la ausencia total de extremidades. PERO, mágicamente saltaran a la vista al teclear un ordenador o recuperar datos. ¿Sentido común? ¿Alguien? De todas formas, no es algo que afecte negativamente la experiencia de juego, pero si están vendiendo una aventura narrativa ♥♥♥ la siguiente frase:

“Tacoma continúa ♥♥♥ la tradición de contar historias de forma detallada, envolvente e impactante, al mismo tiempo que sumerge a los jugadores aún más en la narrativa”

Pues, ya podrían revisar el modo interactivo y al mismo tiempo aprovechar para crear un cuerpo completo y generar animaciones para todas las acciones e interacciones que vamos a realizar. No solo para las que crean necesario, esto afecta directamente a la inmersion. Una vez más volvemos a Giant Sparrow ♥♥♥ What Remains of Edith Finch, un juego que lleva la interacción a un nuevo punto y durante el camino la convierte en un nuevo lenguaje narrativo.

Al fin de cuentas es un título totalmente endiosado por la prolongada sombra de su predecesor, como resultado final recibimos un serio declive para el género de las aventuras narrativas o mal llamados Walking Simulator. Más aún, si tenemos en cuenta el sorprendente trabajo que realizo Giant Sparrow ♥♥♥ What Remains of Edith Finch, una obra de arte.
Los chicos de Giant Sparrow se atrevieron a escribir lo imposible y darle vida a un sueño de temores. Entonces, partiendo de una base tan fresca, funcional y reciente ¿por que caer en un pozo de eterna oscuridad ♥♥♥ Tacoma?

Para leer el analisis completo dirigirse al siguiente enlace:

PC Indie Master Race [pcindiemrace.com]
 
MadMax

3

Recommandé
3.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 février 2018
Tacoma is, in a sense, a mixture of a visual novel and a walking simulator. The story takes place in the Tacoma space station, giving you limited knowledge on your visit, with the first couple of rooms you explore telling you the initial event, and everything after being the individual experiences of the crew and their thoughts/feelings. The game gives you options to review the events on a timeline, as well as exploring the messages and data of the crew as a window to their thoughts and personalities, all so that you may connect with them.

Overall, I liked the story. It gave me the intended emotions at the intended times. The overarching story itself isn't that unique, but the characters themselves are unique from similar stories.


I'd give it a 9/10.

Pros
-The AR aspect is a clever way of telling the story.
-The crew logs help to connect with the crew.
-The overarching story does well in letting events unfold rather than spoiling things initially.
-You can throw things in zero gravity at times.
-Silly (but fun) achievements.

♥♥♥♥
-Price, it's a bit short for the original price. I'd reccommend valuing it at $5 if you're not into visual novels/this type of story telling, if you are into this type of story telling, then I'd say its closer to $10 in value for you depending on your interest level. I picked it up in humble bundle, so it was worth it for me.
-FPS drops when loading in elevators.
-If the game is paused too long, it might crash like it did for me. The autosave is decent, however. No manual save, though.
 
Hangman401

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
6.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 septembre 2020
In Tacoma, you play as Amy Ferrier, a AI specialist, investigating why the crew of space station Tacoma evacuated the station. On Tacoma, you will use AR to recreate different scenes between the crews for you to understand what exactly happened on the station. Throughout the story, you also find out the personality of these people as well as the problems they are facing. Curiosity grows into sympathy, and we start to understand humans never change, no matter they are living in present time or in distant future, humans stay human and all of us face similar adversities but also share sentiment towards love and happiness.

I wouldn't spoil what exactly happened on Tacoma. The journey is short (4-6 hours depending on how much you are a explorer) and I hope all of you can enjoy the ride. It is totally worth your time.

9/10

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
4.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 février 2018
Tacoma is a walking simulator set on a space station. You play as Amy Ferrier, an independent contractor for the Venturis Corporation, one of many corporations operating in the year 2088. Your job is to retrieve the AI off of the evacuated space station Tacoma. While the company reminds you that everything you see on board is confidential, it takes a *long* time for those data transfers to complete, so you might as well look around…

Made by the creators of Gone Home, this is not really a game. Rather, it is a linear story, told via the exploration of the space station, watching segments of the story unfold via the station’s 3D recording apparatus. You can move around and watch the scenes from several different perspectives, listening to various characters as they try to resolve the crisis on the space station, while their oxygen supply runs low, all the while getting guidance from ODIN, the space station’s AI.

The biggest flaw with Gone Home was its ending – the ending of that game was pretty jarring with the overall themes of the rest of the piece. Tacoma, conversely, works a lot better – you get to see all of the pieces of the plot falling together, and it becomes increasingly obvious as you keep making your way through the plot what is REALLY going on.

However, I still have to say they didn’t quite stick the landing. As a drama, this story does a lot better job of unfolding. However, it has one fairly critical flaw – while the characters throughout the story have a sense of agency, it feels like one of the crucial payoffs doesn’t have a lot of buildup to it. While the area where it comes up gives us some background on it, this is very late in the game, after the point at which it was plot critical, which is kind of annoying – while everything else was foreshadowed very well, that part wasn’t, and as a result, it diminishes the sense of agency there.

Still, I have to say that on the whole, the story DID work. The voice acting was on-point, the environments weren’t so big as to be tedious to explore while being large enough to give you some stuff to look at and feel like you were unravelling the plot, and I was overall content with the experience – at the very least, I was never really bored while playing, though the lack of a sprint button felt like a somewhat odd choice.

This is not a walking simulator that knocks it out of the park. But unlike many such experiences, it did at least feel decent to experience. While some people might decry it as being short – which it is, the game took me only in the realm of three and a half hours to 100% – it really didn’t want to be any longer than it was. The story was over by the end of it, and it would not have benefitted from being longer, and would have likely been boring to sit through.

Overall, this is something that you’re likely to be interested in if you like cyberpunk-type stories, about a future society dominated by uncaring megacorporations and AIs, albeit a much more subdued version thereof – rather than being overtly dystopian, the world feels much more rounded around the edges, and it is clear that the megacorps are far from omnipotent, rather being very much subject to the laws of society, albeit laws that they try to circumvent to their own advantage.

If you’re looking for an actual GAME, though, I’d say to avoid this; this is not a game in a very meaningful sense, despite a couple of very simple “puzzles” to unlock a few doors. This is a walking simulator heavily focused on story, and if you aren’t interested in wandering around inside a story that is unfolding around you without much interaction from you, this is not the product for you.

Note also that this IS very short; keep in mind that this is an experience under four hours long. I was fine with that - I got it as part of a bundle - but I can understand that some people might be put off by the $20 price tag, given it is more akin to going to watch a movie in a theater than it is to a game that you are likely to play over and over again.
 
TheTitaniumDragon
2,007 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
14.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 septembre 2017
Gone Home IN SPAAAACCCCEEE

Okay, I have to admit that headline is a little misleading, but when two games share the same developer and has similar mechanics, then comparisons will be drawn. It is only natural. That being said, it is not completely like Gone Home, otherwise I would not recommend the game and direct you to buy Gone Home instead, Luckily, Fullbright Games are not one-trick ponies.

So, what is different?

In most video games the player can only really see one side at the time because you as the protagonist is stuck in the present time. You cannot, say, go back in time and go to another place and listen to what other people have got to say about a situation. This is what makes this game radically different from other games. Under the guise of past AR recording you can reverse, fast forward, and pause characters' conversations. As there will often be several conversations going on at the same time you now have the power to rewind time and follow another conversation. This unique form of storytelling allows you to follow many sides of the narrative at the same time. As you might imagine this type of gameplay will be very hard to write without causing some sort of plot hole or paradox. But the Fullbright team had pulled it off extremely well. It also goes a long way to explain why you get such a short game: it is extremely resource intensive, as you are often telling two or three stories at the same time.

Talking about AR, it features heavily as a gameplay mechanic. The game does a good job of exploring the full potential of AR You receive written messages through your headset, you have things translated for you in floating text above the object, and you see things as they were in the past through an overlay. It of course begs the question: what if those things become commonplace in real life? We know the benefits, but what are the detriments? Who own the data needed to create the AR envionment? And why does the crew's every move have to be monitored this way? Gameplay wise it is very helpful in giving information quickly, and allows for multiple languages to feature in the game while still allowing the the player to know what it says.

What stayed the same?

Several things, otherwise it won't be compared to Gone Home so often in the first place. The prop huning element is back in full force, this time with a lot more detail about the world and the context characters are making decisions in. What makes it different from the previous game however are the references to the outside world. Gone Home is very personal and insular, limited to the experiences of a family. Here you get hints of politics and economics of the outside world that affects possibly millions of people. Sure, you still get personal relationships motivating the actions and choices for the characters, but because they are mature adults they have much bigger elements to consider too. The props themselves are highly detailed and fun to explore.

The setting itself is much the same. Plotwise a large home and a spaceship is very different but gameplay wise you are still dealing with a limited envionment used by several individuals. A spaceship is still a home for them and much alike a normal house there are distinctive communal and personal areas. The only major difference is how you move around the spaceship. The main corridor is zero-G and that is fun to mess around in.

What definitely stayed the same was how well-written the characters were. Each character has different motivations that sometimes clash and each character has something to hide from the others. This affects how they behave around one another. Once again, Fullbright is the master of 'showing, not telling.' None of the personality traits are explicitedly said but they can be inferred. This is due in part of the masterful acting. You get to know the characters well, their habits, likes, dislikes, and their deepest, darkest secrets.

Tl;dr

Okay, I'll still admit it is Gone Home IN SPACE but there are few new fresh takes on gameplay ideas that should keep it interesting for people. In fact, it feels like a promising EP for an awesome album. I sincerely hope other game developers in the future will use the new gameplay mechanics to tell compelling stories like this. If you enjoyed Gone Home you will almost definitely like this game too. Don't just float off, alright?
 
sophie9709
217 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
3.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 juillet 2018
Well, I bought Tacoma back on the Christmas sale without much looking through the developers and publishers: reviews are positive, space setting, nice description. But when I actually started to play it, it somehow reminded me about Gone Home and I decided to check who the developer is. It turned out to be the same old Fullbright. And at this moment I thought that the story will repeat again: idiotic plot, lousy gameplay and nice soundtrack – why have I even bought this piece of… well, you got it. Nevertheless, I was pleasantly disappointed, which cannot not to gladden.

So, I don’t know whether Fullbright understood their mistakes made in Gone Home or just decided to make a game in a different setting (though I hope it’s the former one after all), but the fact is that everything here is made several times better than in Gone Home. The story is nice and interesting to follow. Graphics is stylish and enhances the atmosphere. There is mostly no music, only kind of quiet background ambient while reading staff panels (see below) but, as for me, that’s enough. Gameplay is still exploration and investigation of levels but now it is flavored with “hologram records”: during the walkthrough you will be able to see what the staff did before your arrival, listen to their dialogs and look through their virtual reality panels to find out what they were watching, searching, reading or communicating with during this time. Moreover, you can rewind these records to find out what the staff was talking about in different rooms at the same time. I wouldn’t say that such mechanics is new and unique, but I haven’t really seen it in other games. And it is just nice and greatly fits the game’s atmosphere.

The only drawback I see is the game’s length. No, I understand that such works do not last for longer than 2-3 hours, but you have a feeling that the real plot only starts and game ends on the most interesting moment. Yeah, station and its personnel story is finished but the ending reveals nice details about the game’s universe (plus, it does this even before the ending) and you want to go back to it, to get the story ending. I can’t say whether the game will have a sequel or not – usually such works do not get them – but I would personally recommend the стечение обстоятельств developers to make it, continuing the story, and would gladly dive back into the universe.

So, in the end we have a nice walking simulator in beautiful setting, with nice gameplay and, if with not an excellent, but at least great and interesting story. I would call Tacoma a kind of Dear Esther 2.0 (or maybe even 3.0) and recommend it for fans of this genre, sci-fi geeks and, maybe, space lovers.

P.S. A little bonus for those who finished Gone Home and Tacoma. You may, of course, read this without completing them, but there are some spoilers for both games.

Oh man, I can’t understand whether it’s a company style or just a coincidence but both Tacoma and Gone Home have lesbian characters (But they have no gays! Ooh, discrimination, contempt, feminism indulging, where are the strong men’s love?.. Ahem, sorry, back to the topic). And yeah, you may think that now my “homophobic soul” will start to argue about overtolerance and new liberal values but no! I, conversely, want to commend Fullbright for such an attitude in this game and think that it is performed much better than in Gone Home. Here we do not have “vanillaness” and idiocy like in the previous game, plus, the story doesn’t come to a forefront after first hour of the game (don’t get me wrong, LGBTQ+ stories can be on the foreground but then they must be at least good and have a solid ground – unlike in Gone Home, where the description is about one thing but in the game itself we get completely different one). Furthermore, here we have not young formulaic teenagers but a adult women, who have their characters and personalities and do not make you to throw up with rainbow. Again, I don’t know whether it’s a company style to add LGBTQ+ characters or a really reasoned decision to add gay characters but I can say one thing for sure: in this game it is performed in right and suitable way, in Gone Home – not. And if there are any LGBTQ+ opponents, who would claim that this is a damn tolerance and propaganda, I can only tell you that it doesn’t seem that something is gonna help you but there are also straight relationships in the game, which are also performed on a high level and do not cause gag reflexes.
 
Victoria The Bluehaired
596 produits enregistrés

Évaluation publiée le 20 avril 2020
全成就通关撒花~

挺不错的一款AVG小游戏，流程很短，解谜的部分也极少（就是找密码啦，线索也基本不要太明显），但这种太空未来科幻画风我很喜欢，甚至一度很羡慕这些船员们的生活环境。不过最后发现大公司的阴谋后也是有点细思极恐，TACOMA就这样成了牺牲品……最后给AI申请政治庇护可还行XDDD

成就有一些还是挺有趣并且挺难自己达成的（比如那个字母O我找了半天，但愣是没找洗手间），飞船上的一些细节还是很用心的，比如红黄两人是两口子，但似乎是les（小黄声音明显是女性），在空间站结了婚，俩人正好都在工程区工作，然后小红就搬到小黄寝室了，还搭了双人床【滑稽】

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
