Recommandé
4.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 mars 2019
Tacoma is a great little walking-simulator-style game. It's really short, has a good story, and the game map, while small, is very detailed, — the exploration feels super rewarding, as you learn a lot about the characters and the game world.

The ending is very satisfying, too.

The story can be seen as very superficially related to the events of The Turing Test, which is another great little game — go check that out.
 
rei
2,302 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
6.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 mars 2018
Tacoma is the next game from the people who made Gone Home and while that seems reductive, it’s literally how they say it numerous times. Even the image on the top right of this page says it. Similar to how Into the Breach is “from the makers of FTL, Into the Breach”. It’s probably the best thing to do as this is another game by the makers of Gone Home and while there are some changes, it’s still going to tick many of the same types of points.

I haven’t played Gone home. I’ve heard enough about it and, honestly, it didn’t seem like the type of game I wanted to play. But Tacoma came to me in a recent Humble Bundle and I figured why not? For some reasons even though I’m not big into walking simulators, I seem to play a lot of walking simulators.

The story of Tacoma takes place on a satellite called the Venturis-owned Lunar Transfer Station Tacoma, which is just called Tacoma in the game. The Tacoma is an orbital structure where there are six inhabitants, each employed by Venturis to take care of the orbital station. There is a botanist (for air), a health officer, an AI technician, a (space) mechanic, an “operations engineer”, and the administrator, oh yes, and a cat.

When you reach the station you are tasked with downloading the AI, and as it’s downloading you run around and recover AR Fragments. I don’t know if this is required, but other than standing and staring at a very slow counter, the AR fragments are going to kill the time you’re tasked to wait. They also will show you why no one is around the station to greet you.

One clever trick the game plays is it lacks a hud in your shuttle. Once you walk into the next room, you’re given the tools to look for the AR fragments which develops the hud you see as part of the game. It’s a nice touch for world building and I love the technology they present in the game.

The AR fragments are 3D recreations of events. One early event, the only one I’ll go into detail for, is a when you see people celebrating “Obsolescence day” when they all gather around and have a party. It’d be easy to do this in 10 seconds but the game shows large time chunks. There are about 3-4 minutes in most of these AR fragments, but almost all of them include all six characters (And the cat). You’re able to fully explore the time and look at each character, watch what they’re doing, and figure out how to access more of the station (sometimes).

Each character usually has their own story or they are tied with another character, so to see everything you’re likely going to have to spend at least three times through each fragment, and it makes for an interesting mechanic. This is what they call a “multi-branching story”. It’s not really, it just requires watching the same scene a few times. Not a bad trick but it is still a trick. In addition, there are a ton of bonus data you can get while you recover each person’s screen.

The screen is the futuristic tablet/phone that a person can pull up and talk to the AI, and each time a character pulls it up they have four tabs that you can select. Quite often only two or three tabs are really used. It’s a shame the game doesn’t use the full screen each time, but I love the technology on display. It feels like something that definitely will happen the way we’re going with technology.

There’s also a desk with similar technology, each containing two pieces of intel that usually fills in some backstory for the characters. In fact, all the characters have some interesting information and thoughts at some point, which isn’t surprising because that’s the type of game this is.

There are also personal ARs in almost every crew quarters on the ship. These are…. Well, honestly, I find these to be disappointing. Almost all of them have no motion almost no talking and usually just a song playing. Their rooms are interesting because you get the personality of the people who live in them, and usually some letters or personal objects that let you know what type of people they are. They just don’t have very interesting ARs in them, which feels like a waste when you can get an inside look at the person.

The game mostly takes you through the station allowing you to see all the ARs if you explore, giving you a few very simple puzzles, mostly find the key, or find the code to open everything. There was only one object that was even hard for me to find, but I liked exploring spaces.

And then eventually you reach the end of the game and it ends. I’m not going to spoil too much here but that’s about all there is in the game. It is still a walking simulator like Gone Home. You pick up objects and look at it. The AR recreations are fantastic, and I really enjoyed seeing them, but it doesn’t add much to the formula or even give a real puzzle to the game.

At the start of the game it shows you a basketball hoop which you can throw a ball through within the first 5 minutes, sadly that’s almost all the real interactivity in the game, there’s one more achievement with a puzzle, but it’s mostly the same as all the puzzles of just finding the right objects and place them in the right area.

The one thing I really like is the exploration of the ship, it’s an interesting 3D place. It’s a shame there wasn’t more to do with it, but what there is when exploring the ARs that span entire areas are good.

To get back to the story, it’s quite an interesting story and told in a great way, except that it’s short. The devs call it compact, but it’s not, it’s just short 2-3 hours long.

And well... I’m going to get into some spoilerific territory here, if you want to go in fresh I recommend you play the game. If you’re not sure or didn’t like Gone Home, you might want to check this out.

Tacoma’s authors are… to put it nicely very liberal. The game has three couples that it talks about, and two are LBGT. I mention it because if someone is not comfortable with that, they’re probably not going to like this game. It’s not a major part but I feel it’s a bit shoved in your face at one point. Now it is not a problem for me, but I do take an exception because one of the relationships is a bit forced.

You see, the commentary is blunt. In fact, a lot of the storytelling is blunt, there are discussions of workers struggles. Some of it is done it in a way somewhat worthy of praise. Then in one of the final areas you just get hammered with “revelations” not even hints, but just blunt logs that tell you what actually happened. It’s a story that should have been nuanced that is instead delivered with very little tact, or even cleverness.

There’s also a piece at the last moment, which leaves a lot of questions open. Maybe we’ll see more in this universe but I get the feeling this is a one and done. A shame because there’s something I like about this universe.

Yet I had to discuss the story’s real shortcomings because as a writer who has written a few things, none published, the story here is a bit insulting. People talk about this team with reverence and while there’s a good story here, it just ends on some weak notes.

The game is good when it tries to do something different. I really liked how the station is presented and explored, and the story that happens is pretty good when it’s working.

It’s just a shame that the writing and delivery of the story just doesn't deliver the same level of quality consistently over 4 hours. A twenty dollar game for four hours should be a top of the line experience. Tacoma isn’t at that level and I don’t think it will get the same level of praise as Gone Home. However, if you liked Gone Home, you’re going to like this and even if you didn’t like Gone home and want a more sci-fi based story, you’ll get something good here. I just wish it was a little better.

If you enjoyed this review or want to see what other games I enjoyed you can find my curator page at this link. http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31803828-Kinglink-Reviews/ Give me a follow.
 
King Link
2,935 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 janvier 2019
Очень крутая игра-квест про расследование на заброшенной космической станции.

Вообще в квестах главное - это сюжет. Поисковая деятельность или деятельность по сбору головоломок может быть интересна тоже. Но если мы не знаем, зачем мы эти головоломки решаем - половина интереса теряется. Игра превращается в обычный таймкиллер, а в этой области мало что может соперничать с обычным пасьянсом. Например, я так и не смог пройти Gone Home - из-за скуки, бесцельности и бессмысленности происходящего.

Эта же игра даёт нам явную цель. Мы прибываем на станцию с точным заданием - расследовать случившееся. Мы двигаемся по отсекам, в каждом полностью восстанавливая картину произошедшего. И постепенно для себя по крупицам эту картину тоже начинаем осознавать. А в конце нас ждёт неожиданный поворот. А потом оказывается, что он не один. По-моему это прекрасно. И пусть игра очень коротка - я одолел её за три часа при первом же прохождении - но этого достаточно, чтобы получить удовольствие; практически как от просмотра интересного фильма. История рассказана с душой, увлекательно, вижу здесь старание авторов.

У игры приятная графика и ненавязчивая музыка. В плане геймплея она не злоупотребляет ни невесомостью, ни прогулками с искусственным тяготением по коридорам. Немного не хватает, пожалуй, бега и прыжков - но игра не настолько длинная, чтобы это успело надоесть. Возможно при повторном прохождении это будет заметно, но нужно ли её проходить повторно? Не знаю. Даже все ачивки можно собрать за один раз. Кстати, если вы чего-то не успели - можно прямо даже из-за штурвала своего корабля в последнюю секунду вернуться на базу.

Механизмы дополненной реальности интуитивно понятны - и кнопки, и коды, и способ перематывать историю наблюдений. Всё отлично работает, у меня, во всяком случае, не глючило.

Отдельное спасибо авторам за поиски котейки!

Короче говоря, увлекательная история для прохождения на один вечер. Рекомендую покупать любителям коротких, но интересных игр, я бы поставил 9 из 10.

--
Мои обзоры на странице куратора (на них можно подписаться)
 
Allan

Recommandé
11.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 novembre 2017
I adore this game immensely. It tells the stories of multiple people, how they came to be on Lunar Transfer Station Tacoma, their lives on the ship, and the particular events that led to the members disappearing. It's up to you how much effort you want to put into the story - the more you search and discover and explore and experiment, the richer experience you receive. People crying "wah, £15 for 2 hours!" clearly cannot appreciate the amount of thought and care that went into such a game as this (also, it's longer than 2 hours if you make the effort to explore and not speedrun). The characters of Tacoma are diverse, endearing in their own ways, and so very human, and the world created is somehow familiar, almost unsettlingly so (space capitalism, it's capitalism but now in space), yet still futuristic and fascinating. I loved every second and will happily replay this game again in the future multiple times, to relive the experience of it. The ending still makes me giddy thinking about it.


Also Minny is best AI, I love Minny so much. "Okay~"
 
l'amoureux
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 octobre 2017
Tacoma uses an interesting mechanic to tell a story of a not-to-distant future where mega-corporations have moved into the stars, and the limits and workings of AI - which has become commonplace - are shrouded in mystery.

The experience in Tacoma lets the player control the pace. You explore your surroundings and piece together the story of what happened on the Tacoma. The data recovery system makes the gameplay very linear, but this has the advantage of removing backtracking, and controlling the pace of the story.

The world that Tacoma creates is intriguing, and I would recommend exploring it.
 
Shackie

Well, i loved it. I bought this game because of what i loved in the game "Gone Home" and this really didn't dissapoint. i love the characters and their personalities. I mean for a 3 hour game (its only real downside.) you do really get to feel for them.

If you don't like walking simulators however then this won't be your game but its pretty top tier otherwise.

I would recommend buying this in a good sale but definitely an addition to your wishlist.

2,773 produits enregistrés

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 juin 2020
Tacoma is a "found footage"-type game that takes place on a space station in the future. It's got an incredible amount of content and worldbuilding. The amount of attention to detail is stunning.

As you progress through the space station, you learn more about what happened and the universe the game takes place in. I don't want to spoil anything but the story itself is great too. It's linear, but replaying with director's commentary is worth it, and it's worth replaying if you're a completionist, because no doubt you'll have missed some stuff the first time around. There's no combat or timed events (you can always rewind if you've missed something), making it very accessible physically speaking. Lack of combat doesn't mean lack of content or interaction, because the game keeps you plenty busy exploring. If you don't look around in every direction, you'll miss things :).

The voice acting and sound design are great too and everything contributes to the overall atmosphere so well.

If I have one small remark, it's that this game would be an ideal candidate for a VR remake. That's not a negative point, just me dreaming out loud.

Seriously, Tacoma is great and I recommend it. I would love to see more of this universe in the future.

Runs well on Ububtu 16.04. Had a framerate drop/crash on my old hardware once when a trading card dropped, but that was to be expected - like I said, old hardware. I encountered no bugs.
 
Poesvliegtuig

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 novembre 2020
很电影化的游戏，两个小时就能通关，也正好是一部电影的长度。全程并不需要太集中精力，建议放松的时候拿起手柄躺着玩。

++ 背景设定在未来的太空站上，场景搭的不错，整体还算有沉浸感。
++ 利用“AR”的设定将UI直接做在了场景里，而且效果还不错。
+- 游戏中讲故事用的是《疑案追声》中类似的手法，让玩家可以手动拖动时间轴，用主角的第三视角体验场景复现，应该算是体验不错的讲故事的手法。同样是讲故事，游戏相比影视作品的天然优势就是用户可以有主动性的交互。但是这游戏好像没有把优势发挥完全，时间轴玩法没有《疑案追声》做的好，只利用到了时间没有充分利用可探索的空间——那不就跟看电影没区别了吗，毕竟电影下载下来以后也是可以手动拖动时间轴的。
-- 故事剧情上，大的方面比较一般。主线剧情上结尾算是有个转折，也不过就是好莱坞式的阴谋论（防剧透手动和谐），和好莱坞式的俗气。
-- 同样是故事，细节却还算可以。人物形象也算是塑造的比较完整立体。
-- 有中文，但是有些地方有点机翻。整体问题不是太严重。

个人体验下来还行，算是一路没啥障碍地打完了，中间也没有过于枯燥的环节让我失去耐心。但是不会有再玩一次的动力。
 
八十万骑手总教头

♥♥♥♥: Short (although that is actually a good thing for me because I have so many games and so little free time), and expensive for the length (I suggest buying it on sale if you are tight on money).

Évaluation publiée le 3 octobre 2017
Tacoma is like a short movie, but instead of being presented with only one scene at a time, you have the opportunity to roll back the vignettes and catch up on side conversations. This allows you to more greatly appreciate the ties between characters that you otherwise would have missed.

As an actual game? Its quite short, the objective to advance the plot is straightforward and the occassional roadblocks are easily enough to overcome.

I recommend it, but wait for a sale. 7/10

onmyowntrek

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 aout 2017
Tacoma is an exploration game with minimal gameplay in the same vein as Gone Home, and made by the same developer. It is lore-rich with believable and relatable characters dealing with a crisis that is rather normal for its setting. You’re not fighting necromorphs or travelling through time. Instead, you’re on a recently evacuated space station trying to retrieve an AI. You’re able to see recordings of the crew moving about the station using a neat augmented reality system that allows you to eavesdrop on conversations as well as rifle through their stuff.

With only about 2.5 hours running time, 20 dollars can seem a bit steep. If you’re a fan of Gone Home, this may seem like a no-brainer. If you’re not, but you’re still interested – pick this up when it inevitably goes on sale.

At its full price, Tacoma is hard to recommend. It's competent - but just too short. It’s a solid and interesting game. Grab it on sale.

Check out my coverage of Tacoma on Third Coast Review:
https://thirdcoastreview.com/2017/08/07/game-review-tacoma/
 
Bokor

3.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 juin 2020
I find myself generally agreeing with reviews in this section. This is a perfectly serviceable story, and i like it a lot! But I also agree that the $20 asking price, almost 3 years out from its release date, is a bit much. And that's not a dig on its short length -- there is something to be said in the quality, not the quantity, of hours in a game like this. Still, grab it in a bundle, if it ever appears on one, and you won't be disappointed, at least if you dig the whole walking sim thing.

Recommandé
1.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 aout 2017
This was excellent. I loved Gone Home, and while that was a game about a single person's story, this is the story of a team. There is more interaction, more story, and much more worldbuilding.

Fullbright wasn't able to lean into the culture of the 90s, and instead had to build up the world of the 2080s from scratch. They do a fabulus job.

The game tells a compelling story in a truly novel way in a reasonable single gameplay session length. I've spent so much time imagining Sleep No More, and this honestly gave me the better version of a similar storytelling style. Being able to scrub back and forth between conversations, while also creating enough things for you to do and explore while watching and listenting to scenes play out.

Mooch
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 février 2023
I enjoyed Gone Home. The reason I was interested in playing this interactive narrative was actually because Jacob Geller spoiled it for me in his video on it.

After playing through it, I am left disappointed.

Tacoma, like Gone Home, is very short. I do not have any inherent issue with short games, there are many that I like (and I much prefer them to the plethora of endless open-world games that stick to the same old formulas). Gone Home's short length worked because it was so small. It was about one family, mostly the protagonist's older sister in the mid-90s. There isn't much worldbuilding that is required or necessary, at least in comparison to Tacoma, which takes place in 2088. The world here is pretty different.

The "gameplay" is... fine. I certainly wish there was more to do. Tacoma falls into the common walking simulator trope of putting together the pieces of something that happened before you arrived. Given that everything takes place on the space station, I feel that this game has far less justification than Gone Home to be told through the perspective of an after the fact observer, rather than through the eyes of one (or several) of the crewmates, which I think may have been more interesting. That being said, I appreciate the subtlety of how the game tells its narrative without exposition dumping, which tends to be more common in sci-fi. Thank you Fulbright for respecting the player's intelligence.

The biggest problem is that just as the story starts to pick up the pace, it ends. No climax, no payoff, plenty of unanswered questions. I am especially disappointed because as Jacob talked about in his video, there are a ton of themes on labor and capitalism, which are rarely explored in games this explicitly. I would love to see more games explore complex narratives and themes like these, especially if they can better integrate with the gameplay.

I don't hate Tacoma; in fact, I wanted to like it. I just wish it could have been more fully realized.

I got the game on sale for $3, and at that price I could recommend it if you can enjoy walking simulators. I definitely couldn't recommend it near full price.
 
Iconoclass
248 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 avril 2018
If you would like to read more of my reviews, check out and follow the 𝓕𝓾𝓷𝓴𝔂 𝓙𝓪𝓵𝓪𝓹𝓮𝓷𝓸𝓼 curation page as well as joining the Steam group, feel free to say Hello to the community on the Discord server!

▀▄▀▄▀▄ Tacoma ▄▀▄▀▄▀

I really liked specific things about Tacoma, but as a whole I don't think it's worth more than just 1 play-through. The entire game\story is highly dependent upon you as a player, you could speed through much of it without knowing what's going on and beating the game without much closure. This is a real slow burn, you need to know that before starting the game.

I combed through Tacoma Station absorbing all the information I could to find out what happened to the crew and eventually beating the game. Tacoma has a cool setting with compelling reasons to invest into that world but the crew is the weakest part of the whole thing. All the problems I have with the game are connected to the crew, the writing is too slow and dull most of the time. The crew themselves have interesting backgrounds on paper but none of that manifests itself to how its presented to the player. A lot of random banter and other moments for flavor which all gets thrown out the window when the crisis happens. I could go on, but to say anything else would spoil things for those who already know they are into this type of adventure game.

If the setting or genre is what is bringing you in, Prey 2017 does a way better job, go play that instead.
 
spicygamethunder

Évaluation publiée le 13 aout 2017
Ну и что из того, что короткая игра ? Кино тоже короткое. И ощущение именно , что побывал внутри фильма. Даже цена примерно равна цене билета. Понравилось. 4 часа пролетели как одно мгновение. Хорошее приключение с хорошей музыкой на один вечер.

Историческая, экономическая и политическая подоплека забавны. Порадовало, что космический лифт из кларковских "Фонтанов Рая" построен :-).

Из недостатков - конечно, авторы слегка схалтурили, используя в записях дополненной реальности "скелеты". Уж наверно в 2088 году научатся нормально записывать полные изображения.

0
Recommandé
4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 janvier 2018
Tacoma is a quality Sci-Fi short story, told via an immersive first-person sim, that takes about 4 hours to play through. The futurology world-building is subtle but deep (if you read everything), its themes of workplace automation and the dangers of corporatism are timely, and you really get to know the six crew members well. It's the sign of a strong narrative that I wanted to see these characters succeed, and I don't think the brevity of the gameplay detracted from the overall experience. Also the station cat's name is Margaret Catwood, which is very good.

8.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 mai 2018
This game is truly heartbreaking. I cried my little heart out on my second play through because I didn't play it right the first time around, so I missed many clues and personal letters etc. I know a lot of people think the game is a bit too short, but if you don't rush it, and explore every little nook and cranny, the 2 plus hours of exquisite gameplay is worth every single penny (or dollar, or whatever your currency is!)
I have only cried in a few games, Witcher 3, Life is Strange and now this one. The level of detail in Tacoma is stunning and so realistic that you actually feel like you're on a real job, trying to solve a real mystery, and investigate the issue as best as you can. My tip would be to dig deep and investigate EVERYTHING and EVERYWHERE if you want to complete 100% of each section. I wholeheartedly recommend this game <3
 
Sasha
6
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 janvier 2018
Tacoma is a wonderfully unique experience full of moments, both large and small, that brought joy and surprise. I cherished floating through the gravity-free Hub with the gently encompassing sound of tiny stabilizer jets maintaining my course. I was constantly mesmerized peeking through windows out into space to see the beautiful vistas comprised of planets, stars, and the ever-rotating spires of Tacoma station. I scoured every room, box, access station, message hub, and conversation to gather as much of the lore as I could. I was consistently pleased with what I found. For me, the beauty of the experience was sitting back, relaxing, and absorbing the story, ambience, and scenery at my own pace.

Ultimately, you will get out of Tacoma what you put into Tacoma. If you speed through the story, skipping past the additional side objects, notes, access panels, messages, and recordings, you will arrive at the credits feeling what I can only assume spawned the few negative reviews written here. Adversely, if you investigate the details in the nooks and crannies, take time to explore the rooms, pick things up, look them over, set them back down, and read as many of the messages as you can find, you will come to appreciate the love and effort that Fullbright put into this game.

My only wish is that this game were made for VR...but there's still plenty of time for that, right Fullbright?

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
1.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 janvier 2021
TACOMA
Bienvenu sur la station TACOMA, découvrez ce qui si est passé en utilisant les systèmes d’enregistrement en réalité augmenté de l’équipage pour revivre les dernières 72 h.

Les points positifs :
Beau : graphiquement impeccable
La mécanique d’enregistrement : tout le jeu repose sur cette idée, suivre chaque personne en RA pour pouvoir récupéré un maximum d'info ou de code, et c'est bien.
Personnage bien écrit : l’écriture des personnages ainsi que leur doublage (en anglais uniquement) sont vraiment bons
Très bonne traduction : traduction complète jusqu’à la moindre petite phrase éparpillé aux 4 coins de la station

Les choses à savoir :
Walking simulator : faut aimer les walking simulator, malgré le fait qu’il tente quelque chose avec la mécanique d’enregistrement
Histoire linéaire : déroulement de l’intrigue très linéaire qui vous forcera à suivre un chemin prédéfini dans une station pourtant vide

Les points négatifs
Des tonnes de texte : et qui sont inutilement long et sans intérêt pour le jeu.
Politique implicite : l’idéologie progressiste omniprésent
La mécanique d’enregistrement inutile : malheureusement, la mécanique principale du jeu est au final complètement inutile pour l’histoire, il permet juste de faire passer le temps…
Une histoire sans réel intérêt : tout le déroulement de l’histoire est complètement inutile pour la révélation final avec un dénouement dans l'a ligné idéologique du jeu.
Court : 1 h 30 pour un jeu à 18 euros, c’est insultant

Conclusion : pour un jeu critiquant le capitalisme, je trouve sa hilarant de proposer un jeu un à tellement prix pour sa durée de vie minable. Bref, TACOMA n’est pas réellement un mauvais jeu, mais n’a clairement pas les qualités escomptées pour être vendu 18 euros
 
Lokinafi
278 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 février 2023
Questo gioco mi ha abbastanza deluso. Inizialmente il concetto mi ha appassionato molto. Ho trovato curatissimi i dettagli dell'ambientazione. Andando avanti però il gioco non è riuscito a tenermi avvinto. Si va avanti accumulando faticosamente tanti piccoli dettagli di vita della stazione spaziale, senza però che ci sia mai un colpo di scena degno di nota, e senza neppure avere l'impressione di fare passi avanti risolutivi. Gli enigmi proposti sono terribilmente banali. L'impressione è che il succo del gioco sia nell'assistere a una serie di testimonianze, senza poter dare molto input. Dopo alcune ore di gioco l'ho abbandonato, e non credo che lo riprenderò.

Playing Tacoma was a beautiful, interesting small storytelling experience. Set in space, this game explores the possibility of future use of Artificial Intelligence and Augmented Reality, two topics that have always intrigued me and Tacoma gave me a lot food for thought on. I was drawn into the story after only a very short amount of playing. Exploring the mysteries of Tacoma Station and especially the characters was intrigueing, they soon all grew close to me. <3

+ Intriguing storytelling
+ Strong characters
+ Very good voice acting
+ Incredibly detailed environment
- A bit short for your money's worth at full price

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
5.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 septembre 2017
I love science fiction games. Fullbright took the detailed discovery aspect of Gone Home and put it out into space. As far as the length is concerned, I'd rather play a good short game than a long crappy one. Especially for someone with a hectic work schedule such as myself, I can fully appreciate the game without putting in 20 plus hours. Fullbright was able to fit more into eight characters in a few hours than most games are able to do at regular length, which says a lot.

This is a narrative driven game. In other words, no shooting, running, or epic environments. Like Gone Home, the game is able to give an in-depth look at the going ons in the universe using the environment. If you know what to expect going in and enjoy this type of game then you are in for a treat. Looking forward to what the next Fullbright project has in store.

makilakixki
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 janvier 2018
Nachdem mir damals Gone Home so gut gefallen hat, war für mich ziemlich klar, dass auch das nächste Spiel dieses Entwicklerstudios den Weg in meine Library finden würde. Und da GH damals zu meinem ersten eigenen Review auf Steam führte, möchte ich natürlich auch zu Tacoma meinen Senf dazu geben.

In Tacoma spielen wir eine Technikerin, die den Auftrag erhält, auf der Raumstation Tacoma die dort verbaute Künstliche Intelligenz zu bergen. Dafür müssen aber erstmal die lokalen Speicherknoten in den einzelnen Sektionen der Raumstation wiederherstellt weren. Um das zu tun, rekonstruieren wir anhand der Sicherheitsaufzeichnung der KI, was an Bord der Tacoma geschehen ist und erleben so quasi hautnah alle Geschehenisse mit.

Zuerst mal zum Positiven:
Ähnlich wie Gone Home hat auch Tacoma wieder eine gute Geschichte (deren Ende mir sehr gefallen hat) mit gut aufgebauten Charaktären. Auch die Atmosphäre auf der Raustation ist gut. Die Grafik ist ok, der Sound passt. Die Spielwelt ist stimmig und man kann Unmengen an Details entdecken, die einem oft auch noch was zur Hintergrundgeschichte der Welt von Tacoma erzählen. Auch schneidet das Spiel viele wichtige Themen an, wie z.B. Künstiliche Intelligent und Arbeitsrecht. Auch erwähnen möchte ich, dass es manchmal verschiedene Wege gibt, Infos zu erlangen. So kann ich z.B. den Schlüsselcode für ein Schließfach entweder in den privaten Unterlagen des Crewmitglieds suchen oder ich schaue der Person via Sicherheitsaufzeichnung beim Eintippen über die Schulter.

Leider gibt's aber auch ein paar negative Sachen, die ich erwähnen möchte:
Zuerst einmal ist Tacoma sehr linear, das Spiel schreibt uns genau vor, in welcher Reihenfolge wir die Sektionen der Station zu erkunden haben. Hier hab ich allerhöchstens mal die Wahl, welche der verschiedenen Aufzeichnungen ich zuerst anschauen will. Generell möchte ich mal erwähnen, das die Sicherheitsaufzeichnungen mich zwar mittendrin im aufgezeichneten Geschehen dabei sein lassen, aber auch etwas von der Spannung, des Selbst-Zusammenreimens der Story rausnehmen. Dazu kommt noch, das die Raumstation kleiner ist als noch das Haus in Gone Home. Deshalb sucht man schon mal automatisch weniger rum (was wahrscheinlich das Ziel der Entwickler war), wodurch man viel schneller vorwärts kommt. Und das ist dann auch schon das Hauptproblem, das ich mit diesem Spiel habe: Die Spielzeit ist extrem kurz. Ich habe Tacoma in unter 2 Stunden durchgespielt - das ist weniger Zeit, als ich damals für das ebenfalls nicht besonders lange Gone Home gebraucht habe.

Fazit:
Tacoma ist ein gutes Spiel, auch wenn es für mich nicht an Gone Home rankommt. Trotzdem ist es für Fans guter Geschichten und Spielwelten zum selber-entdecken eine Empfehlung wert. Aber ich rate dringend dazu, nur im Sale zuzuschlagen. 20 Euro für zwei Stunden ist leider kein guter Preis. Ich hab als Besitzer von Gone Home einen Gutschein bekommen, so dass ich ~13 Euro bezahlt hab - auch das fühlt sich noch nach zu viel an. Trotzdem: Tacoma hat seine Stärken und ist einen Blick wert.
 
Locairn

Évaluation publiée le 16 juillet 2018
FullBright 라는 개발사 이름이 정말 어울리는 게임이 아닌가 싶습니다 말 그대로 수작 영화 한편을 보는 느낌이었으며 비쥬얼 분위기 스토리 진행방식 등등이 상당히 인상 깊었습니다 플레이 타임이 짧다고 생각하실수 있을수도 있으나 이것은 한편의 재밌는 영화를 본다고 생각하고 즐기시면 될듯 합니다 상당히 즐거운 경험이었습니다 한글화도 되어 있기 때문에 스토리를 느끼는데 언어장벽의 문제는 없을것이라 추측됩니다. (약간 어색한 번역이 있긴 하나 신경쓸 정도는 아님) 적적하게 신비로운 분위기와 우주를 배경으로 한 곳을 좋아하시며 영화를 좋아하신다면 강력 추천하며 그것이 아니라도 추천합니다.

ps:플레이 코멘터리 모드도 있던데 게임을 다 깨신후 이것을 보며 플레이 하는것도 또 다른 재미가 있지 않을까 생각이 됩니다 필자도 아직 플레이 코멘터리 모드는 플레이 하지 않았기 때문에 다음에 플레이 해본후 후기를 남길수 있다면 남기도록 하겠습니다.
 
KingGoodGame
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 avril 2018
From the makers of Gone Home, Tacoma is a fine example of the kinds of great stories that can be told through video games. While trying to put together the clues of what happened to the crew of the spacestation Tacoma, you're able to replay and watch the lives of the crew as they respond to their crisis. There's something incredibly intimate about being able to follow each crew member, learning about their past and their relatioships with the other crew members, and seeing how they try to cope when they think no one is watching, and I never grew tired of it. If you liked games like Gone Home and Firewatch, you'll love Tacoma.
 
Caparian Sol
409 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 aout 2017
Everyone agrees the storytelling around the crew of the Tacoma is top notch. They're right.

The criticism of Tacoma that I keep seeing is that the narrative is too slow and only gets interesting at the end. Having just completed the game, I'd say to the contrary that I believe Tacoma (very effectively) hits the key beats and notes it needs to set up the world, characters, and plot which then, through a series of revelations, sets up the excellent twists and slingshots the player through the ending. Far from being plodding, I found one of the best (and elegantly told) stories in games told in recent memory, with no chaff or bloat.
 
TechnologoDoom
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 décembre 2018
本作為以「太空站」為探索舞台的步行模擬遊戲，玩家在故事中奉命進入某座空蕩蕩的太空站，回收其中的情報。在玩家探索太空站，觀看過往船員的生活錄影時，發生在這座太空站的事以及主角身負的使命都將昭然若揭。

我認為本作的樂趣有二，其一是大部分的物件都可以拿在手上調查一番，上頭所載的文字能幫助玩家更進一步認識遊戲的世界觀；其二是在遊戲中被稱為「AR紀錄」的東西，啟動後會在當前房間播放六名船員的立體影像，而玩家可以跟在任何一個船員身後，觀察他的行動。某個船員獨自一人收發信件的同時，另外兩個船員可能正在萌生情愫，本作讓玩家得以第三者的身分觀察人與人的互動。

本作約只要兩小時便可全破，全成就的話也只需要三小時，結局則留有很大的空白供玩家想像。整體來說，雖然過程有點意思，但是其文本卻不會讓人想讀第二次，是一部玩過一次就好的作品。
 
OwenFeline

Évaluation publiée le 27 juin 2019
Короткая, но интересная игра о судьбе экипажа космической станции Такома. Рекомендую скорее любителям простых историй о человеческих судьбах, нежели любителями фантастики. Но и они найдут здесь для себя интересные вещи.
По скидке брать её можно точно, а сама игра как по мне лучше их предыдущей или по крайней мере мне она показалась интересной.

I found the story and characters compelling, and the pacing was excellent. The mechanics of the storytelling in the game are super interesting, and I wish there was a little more to the game built around exploring them but that's a minor criticism at worst.

It definitely falls into the category of "walking simulator" though, so if that's not your cup of tea Tacoma likely won't change your feelings.

0
Non recommandé
2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 octobre 2019
Very short and boring walking simulator. This game doesn't have a single puzzle or anything requiring you to stop and think - you just go around the space station, read notes and trigger recordings to unveil a very generic and unimaginitive story. The six crew members are positive and unproblematic to the point of being completely boring and unsympathetic. No personal drama happens at any point, and the plot twist in the end is just as predictable as obligatory lesbian couple, as well as a gay one. I mean, it would be great to see an exploration of some real human feelings of LGBTQ, but these two seemed to have been put it just to score woke point and nothing else. However, they're still better than the straight couple storyline, wich featured the most excrutiating dialog of the whole game (which is quite an achievement).

Overall, not a single original idea, not a single thrilling moment, and I'll never get those 2,5 hours back. But thanks for making it a short one.
 
golergka
884 produits enregistrés
1
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 juin 2019
A fun space "walking simulator" with incredible atmosphere, an intriguing story and touches of mystery. More than anything it captures what you imagine it would be like to live in space for extended periods of time with just a few other people. Much like Gone Home there's lots to explore and your mileage will vary based on your curiosity. I thought all the characters were very well written and had interesting quirks and reactions to what was going on. I finished the game in a little over 3 hours, though I saw some people take 4-5. I didn't speedrun and got almost all the achievements so that was with extra exploring. Maybe not worth full price, but definitely on sale!
 
Ripper
360 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 octobre 2023
As has been expressed in other reviews, the storytelling and dialogue in Tacoma are very well done. The characters are relatable with concerns and inner turmoils that are easy to empathize with. They keep you engaged even when you're delving into the mundane aspects of their lives. The level of detail used to weave together their various backstories within the context of the plot is impressive and I thoroughly enjoyed the experience.

The plot that unfolds brings up real, contemporary issues and keeps the story - taking place decades in the future - anchored pretty close to home. We are given glimpses into how humanity has progressed, and while there is a notable optimism about global prosperity and the expansion of progressive ideals we find that there are innate human flaws and vices that persist no matter how we might strive for perfection or reach for the stars.

This is a game that offers a lot in a small sitting. If you also enjoy strong narratives and detective work this game is for you.

rowsy dowsy rowsdower
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 novembre 2018
Tacoma is one of those narrative games developed by Fullbright the minds behind Gone Home where it's set out to tell you a story. I thought it started out a little slow and didn't grab my attention as quickly as Gone Home did. I also didn't like it as much as Gone Home, but it was a unique experience regardless. The story was pretty good kept me interested enough to keep me playing, but I started to suspect the plot and it's outcome before it was revealed, but it was still a good story in my opinion. Gameplay is similar to Gone Home, you will still walk/float around reading a bunch of text to progress the story until it's conclusion. Tacoma does offer a unique way of telling you a story not only through a bunch of text to read, but also you get to see what exactly happened on the ship before you arrived there by reviewing these events by using a AR device that you have. The sound was good, but there wasn't much that stood out to me personally. The voice acting seem to fit the characters so that's always a plus. Now as much as I liked this game and I know it's said in almost every review, but this game is short plain and simple. It can be beat in 2 hours or so and for the price of $19.99 I would not recommend it, but if you get it on sale and you are a fan of these type of games or you liked Gone Home it's a great experience that I would recommend. Also I did have the game crash on me twice, though the game auto saves so I didn't have to redo any portion of the game and I had no other issues while playing.
 
TheVirus0fLife
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 octobre 2018
To clear up the debate whether this game is worth 20 bucks or not. I have played a lot of indie games and they are generally around 15- 20 USD. And generally it's either a very immersive experience or a good short amount of fun for it's cost. Tacoma is the immersive experience kind, I think the story is kinda normal but I still had a fun time going through the game. There a lot emotional feeling going for this game there's small humor, romance, sadness, tention, fear, and so much more. I personally think it's a great game and it worth the cost and more if you decide to really take your time look around and really listen to what they say and read the messages, it makes you feel for each of the characters.

There is a small replayability but personally I feel like this is one of those game best played once and take your time on it. One thing I wasn't expecting was the great music they have in this game.

Lastly, to make it clear this game is not a interactive action game at all, it all dialogue and reading and small interaction with things, it's just a great story. I give this game a 10/10.

Évaluation publiée le 23 aout 2018
Потрясающая игра. Пишу отзыв по горячим впечатлениям, сразу после прохождения. Она меняет сознание. Что Gone Home, что Tacoma - интересные игры, но Такома на порядок проработанней. Хоть она и коротка, но это было отличное приключение. Неторопливо проходила в течении пары вечеров.
Хочется, конечно, чтобы ее было больше. Но, пожалуй, это такой жанр. Основное количество времени уходит на рассматривание каждой красивой вещички в комнате. Такое либо нравится, либо нет. Эта игра не про экшен, а про самостоятельное вливание в атмосферу, про узнавание личностей героев, когда изучаешь оставленные ими вещи и слушаешь их диалоги. Если нравится такое и фантазия неплохо работает, то добро пожаловать.
 
B-OSS
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 juillet 2018
The real genius of Tacoma is in how there's a lot going on all while it pointedly makes you believe otherwise from the beginning.

Here you are, killing time on the abandoned space station while you wait for the completion of some boring maintenance operation for the benefit of uncaring corporate overlords. So you browse around, poke at the abandoned belongings of the erstwhile human crew, retrace moments in time as recorded by the glitchy station computer. Slowly get to know those human beings of whom remain only faint holographic shadows, in all their messy humanity of personal doubts and frustrated desires.

And little by little you realize how everything, all the little details, fit together, and then you understand what happened here, what is still in the process of happening, and only then does it dawn on you how Tacoma is not just a thoughtful reflection on unusual themes disguised as a walk through a beautifully put together space station: it's also a masterpiece of science fiction storytelling.
 
Balinares
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 avril 2018
Tacoma est un jeu qui m'a fait longtemps de l'oeil avant que je ne me décide enfin et j'ai un peu regretté d'avoir payé le prix fort, je m'explique :

-La durée de vie est EXCESSIVEMENT courte, pourtant j'aime prêter attention aux détails.
-Le gameplay, je ne l'ai personellement pas trouvé intuitif : toujours devoir recommencer les dialogues afin de suivre un autre personnage pour découvrir de nouvelles discussions m'a souvent agacé. Il suffit de rater le moment et on est reparti pour un tour !
-Les moments en apesanteur sont incontrôlables, mais heureusement : ils sont minimes. Impossible d'observer (bien qu'il n'y est pas grand chose à observer dans cet endroit).
-La bande annonce spoil beaucoup (trop) le jeu à mon goût.

Malgré cela, Tacoma a de nombreux bons points, un scénario bien étudié (quoi qu'un peu bateau mais on s'y prête très vite). La fin m'a ravie et l'histoire m'a parue vraiment agréable. Les graphismes sont géniaux, c'est vraiment beaux et les voix se prêtent bien aux personnages. L'ambiance à bord est très particulière : on se sent seul, mais n'est-ce pas ce qu'on peut attendre d'une station spatiale abandonnée? De "petites enigmes" rendent le jeu un peu plus intéressant (recherche de mot de passe etc...).

Je recommanderai ce jeu mais uniquement soldé, car il ne vaut pas son prix. Une très bonne expérience cependant.
 
On Error Resume Next
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 février 2018
Really really nice atmosphere and storyline!

The story plays out on a space station manned by 6 people and one AI. Something happened on that space station and your character is there to potentially recover the lost information.

The gameplay pretty much involves around exploring the space station, observing the visually stored data and going through the crew's personal items for more information.

The characters are very well thought-through. They are all going through their own personal troubles. As you explore more and more of the storyline, you really start to feel for them: even the AI has its own little character!

I would recommend this game to anyone that loves storyline based games.
 
Galaxia
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 février 2018
Relatively short, but has a good story.

I don't want to go really in depth to avoid spoiling things.

You are alone investigating a space station. You interact with recordings throughout the station to find out what happened to the crew.

PC controls since I haven't found them anywhere and it was only showing me Xbox controls:
W, A, S, D: move
LMB: Interact with objects
RMB: Rotate picked up objects
Q: Reverse a recording
E: Fast Forward a recording
Spacebar: Start/Pause recording, skip credits

Minigames: You can play Darts, Billiards, and Zero-G Basketball

I will say that things aren't always the way they seem, and leave it at that.

Oh, and a lot happens in a couple of minutes.

The game's soundscape is nice, lots of things to listen to. The visually different environments thoughout the ship were nice as well, though a flashlight of some kind would have been nice.

DyingOutside
277 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 janvier 2018
This game is a nice sci-fi drama experience. It will of course get knocks for being a "walking simulator", but I think it has a few perks over your traditional pillars of the genre. For one, it uses the medium to tell a story that wouldn't be as effective if it were a movie. It also tells a nicely woven story that builds, twists, but also concludes; it avoids the typical genre pitfalls of overly abstract story telling that often results in vague, unfinished, or unfulfilling narrative.

The only downside I would attribute to it is that, given these traits, it is not very replayable. There is no fail state that I found and no branch or choice in the narrative except your own ignorance. Assuming you explore the world thoroughly the first time, there is no reason to replay it unless you wanted to experience it again as it is.

I've always been one to eye the "walking simulator" genre with skepticism, but if Fullbright makes yet another after this I would certainly take an interest.
 
Yawnslaught
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 mai 2021
2nd game from Fullbright the makers of Gone Home, basically same as Gone Home except now potentially interesting looking place is a space station and that itself would seem pretty neat. Then when you start walking around the station soon you just become attached with very mundane and uninteresting life's of the crew.

As a game it's certainly improvement over Gone Home and looks solid along with having some little things in between investigating station, but the mundane life drama of crew just makes it worse. Think haven't yet come around almost any walking sim that actually simulates living people in it, mostly it's just voice/memory/stationary person.

Alas Tacoma is pretty much as mundane as Gone Home is and walking around station and looking things are basically most enjoyable in it.

10.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 janvier 2018
An enjoyable narrative game where you piece together what happend on an abandoned space station through objects you find and augmented reality recovers that the station AI had saved. Compared to Fullbright's previous game, Gone Home (where you walk around an empty house), it felt much less empty due to this new AR mechanism. Tacoma does have less emotional and nostalgic connect and less detail. All in all, this game offers a short (2-5 hours or so, depending on how much time you spend just looking at random objects, playing micro-gravity basketball, etc.), relaxing experience.

Évaluation publiée le 3 juin 2021
Good story driven game, basically a walking simulator but it's fresh enough to explore a space station to know what happened to the station and the crew, piecing things together as you sit and watch recorded events where only their voices and sillhoutes appear, together with computer logs, world objects, etc. Also fairly short, but for the price tag it's more than worth it, sort of like sitting to watch a movie but you get to set the pace of it and interact with the world..
 
Luiz_Alex007
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 aout 2020
Tacoma is one of those games I instantaneously recognize but never really played (it was rather hard to miss with all the publicity it got when it was first released). So, one foul and miserable day in 2020 I decided to get the game on discount and give it a try—and I'm glad I did.

It's a very short game, mind you. About 4 hours long, and there's not a lot of action going on. It's a story driven narrative where you have to figure out what happened to the crew of a derelict space station. The way the story is told and the way you move through the station is done superbly. I thoroughly enjoyed the few hours I spent on the game and it made me reminiscence on Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey.

In short, if you like story driven walking simulators such as Dear Esther, or are into story driven puzzlers like The Turing Test or (and this is more of a long shot) The Talos Principle then you will most certainly enjoy Tacoma.
 
X-ztnZ
849 produits enregistrés
0
30 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 décembre 2017
Tacoma is not a game. It's a 3 hour visual novel. There are no puzzles, no choices to make whatsoever. You float around, place your tablet in the wall then follow the rat maze back to the tablet. Retrieve tablet, follow instructions to next tablet insertion point, rinse and repeat.

Yawn.

Just watch the trailers and save yourself $20. The game is basically the trailers.

When "watching" the "game" was over the only thought in my mind was "I wish I could have just blown them all out the airlock" as at least that would have been fun.....and a choice I made.

Software like Tacoma should be flagged as a novel and not any form of "game".

I did like playing pool for 5 minutes. Though when I tried to retrieve the white ball after potting it my game promptly ended as my cue stuck to the dart board.
 
Mariner1
5
7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 décembre 2019
Props to the environment design, mechanics of interacting with objects and being able to uncover additional information about the characters beyond what is recorded. I enjoyed the concept of see what happened on a station in this manner ,voice acting was wonderful and their actual scripts were fine, its a good job overall . However the over riding story arc was tedious. I played it for 30 minutes then left it for a few weeks before completing it; sadly there was nothing beyond a simple tried and tested story, it felt incredibly under whelming. Maybe it needed varied outcomes based on the amount you uncover? I don't mind working for an ultimate decision in something or letting your own imagination run wild with what could have gone on only to find its not that fantastical but there was nothing to get invested in. I'm looking forward to other projects the team work on, but I can't recommend playing this sadly.
 
Badbrush

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 novembre 2022
A short and sweet story about a crew facing a disaster in space. You walk around the space station, observe leftover AR data of the crew and look around their belongings to pierce together the story. It's very short, but complete, and the space station actually seems like it could be real in a not-so-distant future. While I would not have paid 20 $ for it, on a good sale this is definitely worth a quick playthrough.

Évaluation publiée le 27 décembre 2020
전작인 곤 홈이 딱히 기승전결 없이 그냥 기록을 읽고 '그랬구나.' 하고 끝나는 이야기였다면 타코마는 제대로 된 시나리오를 갖춘 단편 SF다. 정가는 심각한 오버 프라이스지만 번들로도 풀리고 스팀 자체적으로도 85%까지 세일을 때리기 때문에 3천원 정도라면 딱 제값을 하는 편. 워킹 시뮬레이션이라는 괴상한 장르가 정말 게임의 하부 장르로서 적합한지는 잘 모르겠으나 2~3시간 정도 컨트롤러를 조작해 가며 보는 영화라고 생각하면 큰 불만은 없다. 배경까지 번역한 한글 자막 처리 방식이 대단히 깔끔한 게 장점인데, 오역이 제법 있고 글자가 깨지는 부분이 많아서 전반적으로는 그냥저냥 무난한 편.

AR로 엿보는 승무원들의 일상을 더 많이 넣고 간단한 퍼즐 요소라도 같이 만들었다면 꽤 괜찮은 어드벤처 게임이 될 수도 있었을 텐데 너무 짧고 단순한 구성이 좀 아쉽다.
 
Virus
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 aout 2017
What a fantastic playthrough. About 2 and a half hours and I'm ready to do it again. Its refreshing to play a title that hooks you in the begining and follows through with a satisfying end. Arriving on the space station tacoma, you quickly forget you are completely alone while you are welcomed by the ships a.i. Odin. Except for some questionable transmissions from HQ, you are left with the augmented reality recordings of each crew member and their actions throughout daily life leading up to obselence day. Who were these people, how did they live day to day, and what happened in the end? And how can anyone ever trust a.i? All questions that kept me going with out stop. Eventually you feel a part of the crew, like you were there the whole time, and in a way you were.

The game lets you be in control of the story with play, pause, fast, forward and rewind complements of AR playback. So its up to you to decide where you stand and who you listen to. In a way, you're the director of this story. As you break down conversations and pause to investigate personal logs a larger picture exposes itself. Attempting to make some sort of sense out of everything, the game is paced to keep your attention but not drag. Tensions rise and you are driven to find the anwsers.

My first playthrough was one sitting, and well worth the money considering movie ticket prices these days. This is better than a movie, its a story you experience.You are in control, so the cinematic quality is left in your hand, as with any game. But the art direction, engaging conversations, and underlying story make it easy to achieve.

7小时全成就通关，这个游戏总的来说成就还是很容易拿的，而且还玩梗。
《Gone home》制作组的游戏果然是十分的精致，物品互动做得很细，代入感很强。场景的设计是不错，作为一款偏现实向的太空站走路模拟器，氛围很好，有种置身于太空的宁静，看完剧情瞎逛也是很有意思。世界观的设定，空间站的设定也看得出来用心。AR的界面和人物的处理很巧妙，减少了工作量，却不显得随意，这是款诚意十足的游戏。

A video game like this can create such a strong experience that is more comparable to a good book than to an average video game. Support beautiful games like this.

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
7.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 juillet 2022
While I enjoyed my time playing this game, I don't think I would recommend it be purchased for full price.

The environments and voice acting were really good and very immersive, but I found the whole experience fell a little bit short. Other reviewers have criticised the game's predictable story, which I did not find to be too much of a shortcoming. For me, I felt as though the game failed to properly develop a few plot elements in a way that I found satisfying. Most specifically during the very brief moment we are shown Nat working with ODIN to develop his AI characteristics--I was very interested in how he differed from the other AI shown in the data Nat found, but this was not developed. I would have liked to see more about life on the station prior to the disaster comprising the main plot of the game.

The mechanics of following different characters around during various memories was interesting and I enjoyed learning about each of the characters. I found myself wondering what the relevance of a lot of the "desktop" files were, as the world-building that was frequently delivered through various news articles felt like a lot of reading for very little relevance--they did not really give me more information or insight into what the characters were going through.

All in all, it was a fairly enjoyable experience and I am looking forward to exploring the game with the developer commentary, but I cannot recommend it in good faith. I recognise that my perspective is likely rooted in enjoying slow-paced, narrative walking-simulator games and if that is a way you'd describe yourself, you'd probably get the same enjoyment out of Tacoma that I did.
 
NSV
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 aout 2017
If for you a games worth is determined mostly by its length or difficulty, you may be disappointed by Tacoma's short 3-4 hour length and near-total lack of difficulty. If however you value a game based on the amount of passion, competence and hard work that went into making it, based on the quality of the time you spend playing it, or the hours you spend thinking about it afterwards, then you are likely to enjoy Tacoma.

If you enjoyed Gone Home, you are certain to love Tacoma. Here you'll find the same fine attention to detail, complete with intricately crafted cluttered places which feel natural and lived in, which is all the more awe-inspiring as the game is set in space. (Spaaace!) Here you'll also find many well painted and likable characters, depicted with outstanding voice acting and animated with care.

The augmented reality in the game is a marvelous storytelling device, allowing you to explore a story with many layers of detail and content. We observe what the characters share with each other, and, more crucially, what they choose to hide. Much like a good novel, Tacoma leaves much to the players imagination. The games AR playback represents the approximate position and posture of characters in the room, but eerily leaves out the expressions on their faces and the objects they carry. Thus it leaves the players mind to fill in the rest of the ghostly scenes which play out.

In short, Tacoma is a masterfully crafted game, full of wonder and intrigue. I liked it a lot, and if you've read this far into my review I think you're likely to like it as much as I did.
 
spencer.hargiss
553 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 février 2019
ISS Simulator 2088 - Sponsored by Amazon

Full Review at https://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=251

Presentation
As game development becomes easier with the rise of new technologies and engines, that opens up the window for some developers who might not have a lot of experience designing games to tell a story using only the environment and exploration, pushing gameplay to a secondary place in favor of short narratives. While there have been many such games released in the past years, very few of them managed to tell a powerful story in such a short time and with the few tools available in environmental exploration games, but Fullbright's Tacoma is one of the successful examples. Previously known for 2013's surprise hit Gone Home, Fullbright has took the experience making that game to heart and crafted a truly unique experience, that takes all the stories and interactive objects from Gone Home and strips away the confusing parts and wasted time trying to look for your next objective.

In Tacoma, your objective is clear from the start, which is the moment your character Amy Ferrier enters the Tacoma station after taking a freelance job to check up on a few things aboard the station, from there onward you take on a quest to find out what happened to the permanent inhabitants of the station and why it appears to be a ghost town. Most of the story is told via holographic recordings, which when prompted will show the missing crew talking to each other and interacting with different aspects of the station, while you try to piece together what happened based on those recordings. Once a recording is started you can fully control it, including rewinding it, fast forwarding through it or pausing at any time, this allows you to walk around the area and see where each crew member was at that specific moment in the recording and what they were doing. Using those simple elements, you gradually piece together what happened to them, as well as detailing each character and their personality as you explore their rooms, find recordings of them listening to their favorite music or talking to ODIN, the AI aboard the Tacoma station designed to help them with their daily tasks.

Gameplay
A large chunck of the gameplay is dedicated to discovering, playing and understanding those recordings, on top of the free exploration element which allows you to read documents, interact with various objects and pick up almost any item that you can grab. Even if exploration isn't your thing, Tacoma always points you in the right direction, so even if you don't have the patience to fully explore every area, the game will let you know when you've gathered enough information from one area and give you directions to the next one. That being said, there are not that many areas and the game can be completed in less than three hours, but for a game mainly focused on its story, it packs quite a lot of information and character backgrounds in that time, so it never feels like a longer tale compacted for the sake of time, it just is a very short story overall.

Puzzles are a seemingly missing element that is often found in other games in this genre, as the only puzzle aspect in Tacoma comes from piecing together those recordings and finding out where everyone is at each point in time, but that isn't something hard to do, as areas are not that big and the recording bar also has timestamps for every AR Crew Record, so finding them all is only a matter of time. Every other aspect of the game works as you would expect it to and during my 2 playthroughs I have not encountered a singular bug or glitch, so even though the game can be easily finished in one sitting, at least it will be a smooth ride all the way through to the end.

Graphics
Each one of the 6 crew members has a distinct personality and background, and even though you can only see their faces in pictures or documents since the AR recordings show them as transparent holograms, players who do want to get more information about each of the characters and their job aboard the Tacoma station will be happy to see that there are numerous items that you can interact with to expand the base story. The station is pretty to look at and each different area has a distinct look based on its purpose, but probably the biggest surprise graphically is looking out the window and seeing the station and the contrast between empty space and Earth further in the distance.

Audio
The voice actors do a fantastic job delivering the dialogue for their respective characters, which serves a major part in Tacoma's powerful story and while not every record is voiced and those corrupted archives will stay corrupted forever, leaving you with a disappointment if you were hoping to later unlock them in order to hear more stories from the crew, what is there is superbly written and you can clearly see the story and the atmosphere surrounding it were the main focus here.

Extras
Sadly there is only one ending and the game can be completed in one sitting, so when it comes to replay value unless you're looking forward to replay this further down the road with a fresh perspective, there is no reason to come back. While the achievements may give you an extra reason to explore the station further for some Easter Eggs, all of those combined shouldn't take longer than 30 minutes to complete.

Verdict
Tacoma is a short powerful story about space, the power of corporations and tense relations between humans, as well as an exploratory journey as you uncover every aspect of that. If you are into environmental exploration games with good stories I highly recommend picking up Tacoma, but for anything else you might expect from this game, the short running time and limited gameplay elements might disappoint you.

Rating: 8.1
 
Nighthawk
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 aout 2017
This game has left me with mixed feelings and I'd wish Steam had "neutral" option for exactly such cases. However, I'm going to give it a thumbs up as I genuinely enjoyed it.

Tacoma is my type of game (not everyone likes "walking/floating simulators") and it's really beautifully executed in all ways: brilliant gameplay mechanic with AR, serious attention to details, visually appealing, voice production quality, great storytelling and of course Linux support from day one :)

At the same time the ending was abrupt and not really fitting this semi-dystopian (yet completely believable) setting. But the worst for me was this political message the authors apparently tried to put into it. It's perfectly fine to do that in a medium such as a game but it felt like they're shoving it down the throat when there's no reason to and in a rather improbable way too. In fact, the out-of-place ending is kind of a consequence of it.

Also what's up with USSREU and Euruble... seriously? This very silly touch really ruined the immersion into otherwise perfectly viable game world.

P.S.
Margaret Catwood :D
 
excieve
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 décembre 2023
This game does two things absolutely brilliantly:
- Attention to detail and worldbuilding. The space station is full of everyday objects from 2088 built up to the smallest details, e.g., a can of beef soup has a list of ingretients including in-vitro (lab grown) beef. There are living quarters, a gym, toilets, books, medications, everything ...
- The storytelling. The story is already good on its own, but the way that you discover (by re-living AR recordings of past events) elevates it to the top. Playing through it, I was constantly on the edge of my seat, excited to see what I uncover next.

These two strong positives are in contrast with basically no strong negatives (well, it's a walking simulator), making this an easy recommendation to anyone who enjoys walking simulators or games with good / deep stories.

Tacoma não é a maior maravilha do mundo mas é um jogo interessante, não vale o preço cobrado por conta do jogo ser extremamente curto e não ter tantas coisas pra fazer.

236 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
5.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 septembre 2022
Eu adoro temática espacial e de exploração, o que torna Tacoma um jogo muito incrível é que você precisa explorar uma narrativa que já aconteceu, ou seja, você se faz de investigadora para coletar dados sobre um determinado evento que ocorreu com a tripulação da estação espacial.

Tacoma é uma obra prima à parte com relação a muitos outros jogos, não que seja um jogo com gráficos mega realistas e avançados demais, mas a imersão na qual você é colocado e a construção da narrativa dos personagens realmente é algo que te aproxima da trama e do conceito da experiência.

Eu fiz uma análise desse jogo no meu canal que ficou com uma visão mais completa do que eu poderia escrever aqui, se interessar assista:
Vidéo YouTube™:

obrigada pela visita na análise ✨🎮 tenha um bom jogo

Я узнал об этой игре совершенно случайно, мне просто понравилась обложка. Я не знал ни создателей игры, ни прошлых игр разработчиков, не узнавал сюжет, не смотрел геймплей игры или даже скриншоты, а просто начал играть. И пройдя игру, я внезапно для себя остался под очень сильным впечатлением, а отправившись на поиски хоть каких-то отзывов об игре пришел в удивление от того, как мало людей знает о ней. Nice chill game based on exploration and narrative; not really much to do. Walk around the facility finding clues and unravel what happened to the crew. It was an ok experience.

Juego más que decente basado en la exploración y la narrativa. Su punto fuerte es la "interacción" entre los personajes, interesantes y bien definidos. No hay mucho más que hacer, así que lo definiría como un juego casual de tranquis. Paséate por la estación espacial, recoje pistas/recuerdos y descubre que le pasó a la tripulación.
Es entretenido, sin más pretensiones. Es un juego corrrecto. Si buscas acción, no es tu juego. Si te gusta explorar y ver detallitos, no lo dudes.

140 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 mars 2022
I saw Tacoma so many times on Steam, on various bundles and so on, but never felt intrigued to play it. One of the reasons was that the screenshots and the trailer didn't give me a good impression of the game at all. Now I got it through a Humble Bundle and decided to give it a try, because I heard it's a short game with ~2-3 hours. And yeah, while it was short, it was actually a great experience.

You have to know that I am a fan of walking simulators and I enjoyed games like Gone Home, Dear Esther etc. I really tried to put all of my attention into this game and its story, and for me it was worth it. Don't want to spoil too much, but basically you've been sent to that space station to gather information about what happened by experiencing past events with an AR device. I'm also a lover of AR technology, which was another reason why I enjoyed the game. The characters are all unique and distinguable, the voice actors did a great job and the story was just intruiging enough to keep me hooked til the end. In my opinion, the graphics are also pretty and the performance was totally fine with steady 60fps (tbh, for once was my setup above the recommended specs so that should be expected).

So would I recommend Tacoma? Definitely, if you're a fan of walking sims or if you're interested in trying one, I think Tacoma is pretty great, because it offers a lot of interactability due to how the AR mechanics were implemented. But if you're someone who prevers fast paced action then you should probably skip this.
 
RapperGerste
1,307 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 janvier 2022
TLDR An immersive sci-fi exploration game with an innovative approach to the plot exposition. [18/20⭐, 7h🏅, 1/5💡]

Context Tacoma is a sci-fi adventure game by the same creators of Gone Home, with a similar exploration style. For what it's worth, I find Tacoma to be superior to Gone Home.

Writing The player explores an abandoned space station aided by an AI, piecing together the events that occurred before the game action by collecting recordings from the crew. The game is very well written, and these recording expose the event by focusing on the interaction between the various crew members. In fact, in terms of plot, I’ve felt that Tacoma suffered from the opposite issue of Gone Home: while the latter hinted at a mystery that did not actually exist, Tacoma gives no hints about the conspiracy affecting the game events until very late in the game.

Aesthetics The in-game augmented reality is one of the smartest ideas I’ve seen to interact with the game world and expose plot entries as you move throughout the station (which to me was one of the less credible points of Gone Home). The “recordings” give a ghostly feeling that contributes to the mystery surrounding the station (and I love how sometimes you see the state of the station after the logs, and have to extrapolate what the characters were doing). The level of detail dedicated to designing the station makes the environment credible and that the inhabitants are real people (and also that there is a world outside the station in 2088). The voice acting is great, as well as the soundtrack (like Gone Home, Tacoma also relies on diegetic music to provide further immersion, but it’s not as central).

Gameplay If you played Gone Home, Tacoma is similar in terms of mechanics: it is mostly an exploration game where you progress by finding something akin to audio logs, with little to no puzzle solving. But “progressing” is not really the point of Tacoma, but rather freely exploring the station and piece together what happened to the crew. You can't die or get into deadlocks, the game auto-saves and you can always revisit other parts of the station.

Value Tacoma is not a long game (my 7 hours include a second playthrough with director’s commentaries enabled, not needed for the achievements), although it's within the typical for a game of this kind: when every room is as detailed and unique as in Tacoma, reflecting the personalities of its inhabitants, it’s maybe unfeasible to extend it further. There is a single progress slot. Achievements are related to exploring optional interactions and finding collectibles. After finishing the game you can get back to the last checkpoint and keep exploring the station, so no need for multiple playthroughs. This is the kind of game that is only replayable for the immersive experience.

For more puzzle-game reviews and curated lists check out the Puzzle Trove.
 
macwh

119 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 octobre 2021
리턴 오브 오브라딘 같은 게임.

나온지 한참은 된 게임이지만 ReiPatcher가 적용되는 것을 이제서야 알게 됐다.

구글 자동번역기로 한글 진행하는 방법
1. 파일 다운로드 - 아래 링크에서 XUnity.AutoTranslator-ReiPatcher의 최신 버전 파일을 받자.

https://github.com/bbepis/XUnity.AutoTranslator/releases

2. 다운받은 압축 파일을 게임 폴더에 넣고 압축 풀기

3. SetupReiPatcherAndAutoTranslator 실행

4. 폴더에서 실행파일_x64 (Patch and Run)으로 실행, 종료

5. AutoTranslator 폴더로 들어가서 생성된 config.ini 파일로 들어가
language = ko, fromlanguage = en, MaxCharactersPerTranslation = 500 으로 수정

6. 폴더에서 실행파일_x64 (Patch and Run)으로 실행

7. 게임 실행하면 텍스트들이 강제 자동번역되어서 나옴 (살짝 기다려야 뜸)

8. 이후 스팀에서 실행에도 번역되어 나옴

** 강제 번역기가 다 그렇듯이 겨우겨우 무슨 말인지 알아먹을 수 있는 정도고 제대로된 뉘앙스는 알기 어려움.
그래도 언어 때문에 전혀 못하던 이들로써는 도전할만 할 듯.
 
feveriot

8.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 mai 2021
i enjoyed it immensely. the suspensful feeling of entering an empty station with no prior knowledge of what had happened there and also finding all those recordings, adding a layer of "ghosts aboard station" feeling to it made me a bit paranoid ngl.
the bits of the characters lives back on earth and their personalities through interactions with other crewmates introduces them well enough. we dont really dive deep into their personal stories but i think we are shown just enough to add to and complete the story. the voice actors are really great and the station along with its view of space was very captivating.
i like picking up stuff, examining them and just looking around everywhere so it took me 6 hours to finish. i am a slow reader yes and its doable in 2 hours for some, sure, but if you really want to get the feel of the game i recommend taking your time with it. its worth to wait for a sale though since the story itself is indeed very short.
 
iliann
